151302229.review:
I like this game a lot, but I have a great problem with it :

The combat is so dumb, its laughable. 
I'm playing on Merciless, which should actually be called "Waste your time difficulty", because after you fail an encounter in the dungeon, you can only get back to the title screen (you better save every second you can or you'll regret it). This would be fine if there was any depth to the combat in terms of strategy...instead its all about weaknesses and status effects (if the enemy has no weakness). So to find a weakness (at least 30 hours into the game) you have to attack the enemy to see if its weak. There are many different attack types so experimenting will cost you turns if unlucky. But when the enemy hits you, its most of the times game over and back to the tile screen. Encounters are then trivialized once you see what types of dmg the enemy can do. I literally no brained a boss, because I had a persona negating all dmg from it...that's how trivial it can be and its disappointing. For a game that has sooooo much love put into it to fail so miserably at combat, which for me is a major part why I like turn base games, is beyond mind boggling. So many different mechanics, so much variety but when it comes all together its much much less than the sum of its parts.

Everything else about this game is Amazing! The story I like quite a lot, the mini games and the characters are very good. Also the philosophical questions it poses are great, but when it comes to the actual game play its disappointing.

151252718.review: When my friend first told me about the premise of Persona, I laughed at him (I know you're reading this Vick, ur still a loser for playing P5) because it sounded ridiculous, but there's a certain charm about it that you can't really get anywhere else. The turn based combat is the best I've ever played, I've gone entire palaces not being hit from how you can optimize fighting and the seemingly mundane day to day isn't all that mundane at all. There's a certain confidence Japanese developers have with just letting the player go and figure out the game themselves, and while the combat and palaces have tutorial on tutorial at the beginning, the normal everyday life is oddly free despite being constrained to two actions per day. If you want to soft lock your game because you wanted to be antisocial, that's an option. If you want to [spoiler] romance Dr. Takemi, the hottest video game character in existence [/spoiler] and only see her every day, that's also an option. Atlus leaving the player to get lost on the first day in the train system is hilariously, a good example of the player being taught about the map layout and the train system. I don't think I'm in the target audience for Persona, personally, [i] I barely [/i] even watch anime but I love Final Fantasy so I figured I'd give it a spin, and I did not leave disappointed, and I don't think you'd leave disappointed either.

150997350.review:
[h1]WARNING. SPOILERS AHEAD[/h1]

Wow.

Not even know where to start. And, again, be wary, [b]there are plot spoilers ahead![/b]


The end of the semester and the high school festival has been marked by the rise and fall of the Phantom Thieves by the public opinion. I think this portray very well our society, whose only objective seems to be the desire for great heroes to be praised and evil villains to squander expressly. Throwaway stories, superficial connections created in order to trample and stand out above others, and sacrifices of people in the name of progress.

The whole topic of public opinion, how we perceive others and how it influences us has been growing more and more as it reached the culmination of the main story, completely breaking the stigmas of Japanese society about corrupt politicians, the media being controlled by the government and manipulating public opinion (and I see this is as a world-wide issue).

This has resulted in the creation of a god of Control who had been with us longer than we thought, even kidnapping good old Igor and splitting Lavenza into Caroline and Justine just to keep the façade of our Velvet Room. And the great revelation: Morgana was not only not human, but she was also a creation of Igor with the remnants of hope that there was on the part of humanity, in the purest Pandora's box style.

The final battle with Satanael behind us has been wonderful, at the top of the center of Tokyo and with Shinjuku invaded and fused with Mementos. Seeing how the God of Control became more dangerous, thus causing the "awakening" of the people, has been a very epic culmination of the main story.

Akechi as a villain has been a slow-cooked delight, even having him as a temporary member of the Phantom Thieves. Also, this kid has had ALL the references. He has been a Light Yagami with Berserk-esque villain overtones by way of his second true personality. He has been a clear target for all anime fans serving up personality, charisma, and a tragic past typical of this type of character.

I could say much more, but we DON'T STOP. Right after the end of the year, we started directly with the content of Royal. And I think that could do for ANOTHER lenghty review for itself, as its whole evitation theme and who Maruki wants to create a tailor-made reality for each of us to be happy.

I think it's clear enough that Persona 5 Royal is one of the deepest, mot extensive Persona out there and the culmination of the formula in a large scale (Persona 3 was the first and Persona 4 was in a little town scale).

Let's see what Atlus has for us in the future of the Persona series!

150950020.review:
[h1]So good that I bought it 4 times[/h1]

I know my reviews are long and I appreciate the time you taking the time in reading them. 

I own Persona 5 on the PS3 and PS4, Persona 5 Royal on the PS5 and on PC. Look I’m fully aware that by buying every re-release of a game I’m part of a problem in today’s gaming industry. Gamers being squeezed for every last penny they’ve got, more so with fans of a particular game or series. “They love it, so they’ll buy it anyway”. And Atlus certainly has proven itself to be part of that side of the gaming industry that wants their fans to pay the absolute maximum, because they know that we’ll buy it anyway.
It's just that most of their games are some of the absolute best ever made, and Persona 5 Royal, for me, is probably on top of that list. It’s everything I hoped a game would be as a kid and here’s why.

[h3]A childhood dream come true[/h3]

When I was a kid I used to read tons of comics, hundreds of them a year. My parents bought me a little tape-player (yes, I’m that old) and every last cent of my pocket money was spent on either comics, music, or audiobooks on tape. It was much cheaper than buying a CD and the selection they had on certain events was just insane. Laying in bed listening to every story over and over again, my eyes closed and imagining I was part of every journey. No matter if I was Tintin, Spiderman, Wolverine or Asterix, I loved every story and I’ve been a part of many of them.

I wasn’t all too familiar with Atlus-games in 2016, but I saw a trailer for Persona 5 and immediately added it to my wishlist on the PS-store. The more I checked out some early-on impressions on YouTube and read about it, I became aware of the huge passion the fans of the series had. Apparently the Persona series (and ofcourse Megami Tensei as a whole) had quite the legacy, which only made me more excited to play the game. 

In April 2017 I was sitting on my couch, watching the download of Persona 5 crawl along. I felt something that I felt when unwrapping a new comic or tape. A mix of anticipation, excitement and a hint of nervousness. It’s done. The Atlus logo is displayed, the music starts, goosebumps. And suddenly I’m not sitting on my couch anymore, I’m part of the Persona universe, each morning I’m waking up in an attic, I’m Ren/Joker.

[h3]Masterful storytelling[/h3]

Ren’s a high school student accused of assault and therefore put on probation, his parents decide that he’ll go to another school and stay with their family friend Sojiro Sakura. There he’ll become part of a story where adults are taking advantage of their (social) positions, most of the time to the detriment of children/young adults. Ren/Joker gets to know these victims, befriends them and starts to form his own social circle in this new city. Adults who become so distorted by their own (wicked) desires form a so-called palace. A place where they are the rulers and anything what they want to be in real life becomes reality, influencing their behavior in the real world. Ren and his friends infiltrate these places (palaces) and try to take away the thing that feeds these adults to behave the way they do (a treasure). 

Persona 5 does an impeccable job sucking you in their world. The way the story unfolds is on a level I’ve experienced maybe a handful of times in gaming. Yes, it’s a slow burn the first couple of hours but with good reason. The game starts in the middle of the story and after you are introduced to the stories’ setting you are thrown back to the beginning. So many questions arise: Why was I there, what was I doing in a casino of all places, who betrayed me? 

When you get to the free roam part of the game you’re several hours in. It’ll definitely be worth it, but if you’re more into the ‘dive straight into the action’-type games, be aware of this. But I hope you can find the patience because otherwise you’re missing out on one of the greatest stories ever told.

Persona, for me, feels like I’m reading a comic and all of a sudden I’m part of the story and certain choices have an impact on MY friends, on MY town, on MY family. I don’t want to disappoint any of them, which make some of the choices so hard and so genuine. Who to spent time with? Who to date? Who to deepen your bond with? To balance all these choices while also trying to improve your own (social and combat) skills feels just like real life. I don’t want to say no to any of them, but I’ve got to think of myself as well you know?  I am Ren/Joker, these choices are mine and I must deal with the consequences. 

[h3]Perfect gameplay[/h3]

P5(R) stays true to the turn based genre and to earlier Persona and to most of the Megami Tensei games. If you’re familiar with them than P5R brings very little new stuff to the table, but it’s probably also the reason you’ll love this one. The game is divided in 2 forms of gameplay. 

First the dungeon crawling, action focused gameplay takes place in palaces/Mementos. Here you’ll face ‘shadows’, fight them, gain new (fighting) skill and collect new additions to your team. Second is social part of the game, here you can explore the city, train social/life skills and socialize with a wide variety of people struggling with society. These social connections are a large part of what makes P5R so great. Each of the social connections has their own backstory. Some struggle with past mistakes, some with financial issues, are being bullied or are even unaware of who they really are. With each step you get to know them more and just like a real friendship they try to help you along in life, just like you‘re helping them. 

The balance between the 2 gameplay types is great. Whenever you reach the limitation of certain confidant/social storylines the main storyline advances. Giving you several hours of action-filled gameplay, which advances everyone’s story and gives you a new purpose to focus on when the social aspect again becomes the main focus. This ebb and flow of different kinds of gameplay keeps you invested, interested and makes it hard to stop. There’s always something new to see, learn and love just a couple of minutes away.

In the last 6 years I’ve played P5 (including Royal) 7 times. Depending on the difficulty setting and your interest to explore every part of each confidant, it should take you anywhere from 70 to 120 hours to complete. New game plus lets you keep items and social skills from the previous playthrough, which gives you more time to deepen the relations with the people around you and encourages you to choose an increased difficulty.

[h3]I’m not crying..[/h3]
The amount of times I’ve had goosebumps from profound emotional moments is insanely high. Moments where you can’t help but yell at the screen be it from happiness, anger of sadness. And when the story reaches it’s inevitable peak and conclusion it felt like I was saying goodbye to my own friends and family. You know that feeling when you’re watching the last scene of ‘Friends’ (or another series that’s close to your heart), ‘Embryonic Journey’ by Jefferson Airplane starts playing and you feel the tears welling up in your eyes. You’re torn somewhere between a feeling of love, loss and happiness to have been part of something truly special.

P5R does that to you. It makes you want to instantly play the game again but also to keep a distance for a while because it takes time to recover from something that you so deeply love but eventually has to end.

Persona 5 Royal is hands down the best JRPG I've ever played. Its also my first Persona game, so it also served as a great introduction to the series for me. I was first introduced to the series in 2020 by my friend who owned this game on his PS4, and recommended it to me knowing I'm a huge RPG fan. But I couldn't play it at that time because I never owned a console and only had a PC. That's why I was so happy when Atlus finally announced that the game would be ported to both PC and Xbox and I'm glad I bought it. 

The story is one of the best aspects of the game, and kept me hooked from start to finish, with its amazing characters and world building. It is filled with both happy and sad moments alike, with a lot of twists and turns. The turn based combat is phenomenal and engaging, and the boss fights were really well done. All the extra content they added with Royal were amazing and [spoiler] the Third Semester and Maruki's fight  [/spoiler] were my favorites. All of the side activities, like the mini-games, confidants, were really well done.

Overall, if you are a fan of turn based JRPGs and are looking for a mystery filled story with twists and turns and amazing characters and combat, definitely go for this game. 10/10

149983539.review:
Persona 5 Royal is a brilliant experience--memes aside, it really does let you engage with a solid, well-told supernatural mystery/thriller story while also letting you role play as a sarcastic, somewhat sullen but good-natured 17 year old in the heart of Japan: Tokyo.

You are a nameable protagonist who discovers they can control a persona, a concept of Jungian psychology depicted in the series as monsterous manifestations of international demons of folklore and villains/antiheroes of classic international fiction--from Japanese kami and demons to Egyptian/Greek/Norse/Gaelic mythological monsters. From Arsene Lupin to Captain Kidd. Using these to battle Shadows (the opposite of Personas in Jung psych), you along with a colorful cast of characters will take down oppressive adults and take their heart's treasure. Combat is a hyper accessible yet deep spin on traditional turn based combat known as the Press-Turn system. As a general hater of turn based combat, its fantastic in this game, mainly because menus have been done away with as best they can--each button on the controller/near the WASDs corresponds to a battle action, a single button will target the weakness of a known enemy, and damage is relatively high on both sides. By targeting an enemies weakness, you not only knock them down, you gain another turn during which you can finish off the opponent, target a different one, heal, or you can pass that turn down to a teammate who can then target a weakness and pass their free turn down to the next person, effectively giving you 8 turns in a fight before the enemy can react should the circumstances be ideal. weaknesses can also be "created" via technical attacks--shattering a frozen enemy, hitting a sleeping enemy, attacking the mind of a confuzed enemy, etc.

Outside of typical combat, you will spend time answering questions in class, and with those companions in the real world, deepening your bonds with them either through a heartfelt conversation, or by playing pool/darts, cramming for exams together, fishing, or going to see a movie. If your character is more of a loner, they can also read lots of books, visit the batting cage, fish or play the aforementioned games by themselves, work a job or five, meditate at the temple or pray at the shrine. Almost everything will refine your character in some way, whether it be a social stat increase (knowledge, guts, charm, kindness, proficiency), a bond increase, or a new item, if not a combination of all three. You will have to properly manage time in increments to do what you want; a blind run is best done without thinking about maxing out every stat and confidant, and rather just focusing on what you think your character finds most important, as you simply cannot 100 percent the game on a first run.

The characters you meet are all good if not great. On the surface, they all slot neatly into archetypes so they never get confusing as they all have a unique personality. but as you dig into their lives you realize that all of them are dealing with realistic problems and will also grow over the course of your relationship. Each "confidant" is a satisfying substory to engage with narratively but also, each will give you keep combat abilities. those who don't directly assist you in combat but are still confidants will grant you powerful items to buy or deeper tactical knowledge. As you progress through the female confidants (yes, ANY of them, including the adults), you will eventually be able to start relationship with them, which can lead to some cute moments, some awkward moments, and if you date ALL of them, one really funny moment. Sadly no gay representation though. Comparing this cast to persona 4 is hard as this game generally goes for a much darker tone, so these characters are a lot more focused on their own serious questions about their lives, whereas 4 is much more "scooby doo" in it's approach.

Graphically, P5R doesn't top any charts--it'll probably run flawlessly 4k 60 fps on any rig from the last 5 years, but _artistically_ this game is something else. This game does what Into the Spider-Verse did for animated movies for anime-inspired JRPGs. Very striking use of color and moving jagged edges for menu boxes along with powerful animations, popping particle/damage effects, and very simple transitions into 2D frames keep the screen alive with energy, even during the moments of calm dialogue, while also keeping every element, every piece of action entirely readable, which is an absolute feat.

The music is also fantastic. Shoji Meguro will hopefully soon be known as one gaming's greats alongside Koji Kondo, MIck Gordon, etc. The acid jazz blended with funk is lively when it wants to be, calm when it needs to be, but always iconic and highly memorable earworm tunes. Palaces all have multiple variations of the same melody to shake things up and the songs that play during emotional moments perfectly accentuate these moments. These are the kinda songs that actually might come into your head while living your life. The times when it diverges into orchestral rock feel appropriately dire yet epic. My one major complaint here is that the original intro song, "Wake Up, Get Up, Get Out There" is much better then this one, but its still really good.

Its funny to see how universal the love for this game is, but that cliched IGN saying "theres a little something for everyone" ALMOST applies perfectly to this game. You really have to give it about 6 hours before it "turns you loose" and really lets you start to do things on your own--its partially hand-holding, but its mostly just because there is a lot in this story to set up, and it really prefers to go slow with it. Once you get going, it should be easy to find something to really love about this game. The reason i come back it over and over is that it sucks you into its vibe so easily. A group of friends, an effortlessly cool soundtrack, and a genuinely compelling mystery.

149757136.review:
Persona 5 Royal es, sin lugar a dudas, el pináculo del género JRPG. Con una narrativa cautivadora y una mecánica de juego pulida, este título se alza como una obra maestra que cautiva desde el primer momento.

Uno de los aspectos más destacables es su combate ágil y dinámico. La fluidez con la que los personajes ejecutan sus habilidades es asombrosa, brindando una experiencia muy entretenida.

Los diseños estilizados y vibrantes de los personajes y escenarios, combinados con una dirección artística impecable, crean un mundo que parece saltar de las páginas de un manga. Cada rincón de Tokio y sus Palacios es una delicia visual que te sumerge en esta extraordinaria trama.

La historia es digna de un anime de renombre. Llena de personajes intrigantes y temas profundos, la trama teje una red emocional que te atrapa y no te suelta. A medida que te adentras en los secretos de los Palacios y desvelas los oscuros misterios que rodean a los antagonistas, te encuentras ansioso por descubrir qué sucederá a continuación.

Los personajes principales son el alma de esta aventura. Cada uno de ellos es un individuo complejo con sus propias luchas, sueños y arcos de desarrollo. A medida que pasas más tiempo con Joker, Ryuji, Ann y el resto del grupo, es inevitable no sentir un vínculo profundo con ellos. Esto también se aplica a los personajes secundarios, que están igualmente bien construidos y aportan capas adicionales a la trama.

Las mecánicas y minijuegos añaden una capa adicional de profundidad y variedad al juego. Desde gestionar tu vida estudiantil hasta explorar los Mementos en busca de tesoros ocultos, cada actividad se siente significativa y enriquecedora. El abanico de opciones disponibles es impresionante, permitiéndote personalizar tu experiencia de juego de innumerables maneras.

Aunque el extenso calendario y los Palacios prolongados pueden resultar un desafío, también son testimonio de la riqueza y la inmersión que ofrece el juego. Cada día cuenta, y cada Palacio es una prueba de habilidad y paciencia que te recompensa con una sensación de logro palpable.

En resumen, Persona 5 Royal no solo redefine el género RPG, sino que establece un estándar inigualable en la industria del videojuego. Con una historia cautivadora, personajes memorables y mecánicas pulidas, es una experiencia que no debes perderte. A pesar de su longitud, cada momento invertido en este mundo es una inversión valiosa en una aventura que quedará grabada en tu memoria mucho después de haberla completado.

149293390.review:
I am a 65 years old father with a teenage son who loves playing video games. I have always struggled to connect with my son as he spends most of his free time playing games online or watching others play on YouTube. As a busy single father, I found it difficult to spend quality time with him.

But recently, my son introduced me to a game called Persona 5 Royal, and I decided to create a Steam account so we could play together. It had been decades since I last played a video game, so I was quite rusty. But my son patiently taught me how to play and we started bonding over this game.

I was pleasantly surprised by how much fun we had playing together. It was like we were solving a mystery together, laughing and having a great time. Playing video games with my son reminded me of the joy of being a kid and it helped me to connect with my son on a whole new level. We even started spending more time together outside of the game, going on walks and enjoying other activities.

As a single father, it can be difficult to find common ground with my son, but video games have given us a new way to bond and spend quality time together. I am grateful for this opportunity to connect with my son and make lasting memories together!

Arigato to Atlus for making this game, Shoji Meguro for composing the music and Futaba for curing my ED!

One of the best games ever made! The story is engrossing. It unapologetically deals with demons like suicide, sexual harassment, and existentialism. There are many layers within the story and they also do a great job at basic tropes. For instance, a character struggles with their moms passing and their own guilt, and I've never related more, all while making it an incredible boss fight and fun challenge. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll be excited for more and even though it is very long you will be upset knowing at some point the game will end. I'm only halfway through I believe, just before you unlock the last main character. The world building is unlike anything I've ever played. Every character has depth. You can make decisions that have impact. There are multiple romance options. You make great friends. It checks a lot of my boxes. I cant wait for more releases as Atlus has truly done something special here. 

To be fair I will include what I dislike about the game

There is a general underworld area that merely serves to farm xp to grow stronger so you can more easily battle enemys in the main story. it is more of a time pit then feeling like your fighting for something important. Luckily you are not required to go here too often.

149067758.review:
Eeeuuuuurrrrgggghhhh

Persona 5 is a thoroughly, extremely, excessively competent JRPG. 

What is good?

The presentation is brilliant. The visuals - beautiful! Striking! Delicious! The soundtrack is delightful and fun (if lacking in variety considering the game's scope)

The setting is pretty cool. It's a cute version of Tokyo, full of life and activity.

What else is unique? Three things.

First, the dungeons in this game take place inside villains' heads. You fight within their unconscious. A great idea! But most of the time this consists of fighting pumpkins and endless variations of sexy women with wings. The villains also each represent one of the seven deadly sins. As you can imagine, these different ideas - the unconscious, funny little odd creatures, and bad concepts from medieval Catholicism - don't match up.

Second, you play up against a turn limit. Each day is divided between day and evening and you can take one main action in each. This could mean that you are tasked with making deliberate choices about which skills and relationships to prioritise. I started playing like this. 

But over time you realise that most of the time you do the activity with the person when they invite you, otherwise you do the skill that has a bonus right now. You can't push relationships forward much outside of this. There's not much to be gained from either optimisation (not needed) or specialisation (you can't. You're pretty much the same regardless of playthrough).

Third, you fight with personas, which are a bit like Pokemon, and can merge them, sacrificing one in the process. The Persona menu is unwieldy, and collecting Personas doesn't work well, because you can only have a limited number at a time. And if you move too quickly through the menu then a character shouts at you, which got annoying.

I got 30 hours in, up to the third dungeon (of 7 I believe) and I was tired of the core of the game. Everything else about it is *fine*. The characters are fine, the story is fine, the gameplay is fine, the dungeons are fine. But you can't spread mediocrity over tens of hours and create an engaging experience. The aesthetics can only take it so far.

There are clearly lots of people for whom "RPG of average quality story & gameplay with brilliant presentation spread over 100+ hours" is appealing. There is a lot of game for your money. If that's your cup of tea you will like this! I feel like if I were younger,  had less alternative choice, and hadn't read the equivalent of generic YA stuff many times this could appeal. But for me, it did not work.

If I gave it a rating out of 10 it would be a 6.

Think I've gone through three playthroughs of P5 now. Royal i've finished twice, now.

It's decent. Far from the best in the franchise and the main game is way too easy. My most recent playthrough only used Arsene, upgrading that with skill cards and strengthening it, but even that wasn't really enough to make it challenging.

The final fight of royal is especially dissapointing. it's one pretty mediocre fight followed by a cutscene fight that's underwhelming. I recall one shotting the second phase with Lucifer on my first run. I think Baton Pass really ruins the difficulty of the combat in this game, and am not the biggest fan of how buffed it got in Royal. Somehow the Okumura boss remains the most challenging in the main story, because it recognised how to challenge the overpowered Baton Pass system.

Everyone also praises this game for having good dungeons but I'd honestly prefer strange journey warp puzzles to some of the pretty dull shit that this game makes you do. They're passable dungeons for the most part, and incredibly hand-holding in places. They're fine, just not really that interesting.

The story is alright, but it drags a lot in places. Peaks and valleys, starting off strong and dipping back and forth over and over. Half of the palaces in the game suck narratively, and most of the antagonists are pretty uninteresting. Kamoshida, Futaba, and the third semester are the highlights arcs of the game, whilst everything else is pretty middling to me.

Good game. P4 is leagues above it, but at least it's leagues above P3.

None of them come close to P1 though lmao nanjo sweep

148834121.review:
- Okay enough story to keep you invested, a lot of satisfying moments of character development too
- Somewhat engaging RPG gameplay
- Drop down banger OST
- Very stylish and unique presentation

- "Blank slate" silent protagonist BS is difficult to identify with and kills the flow of the story/makes scenes feel awkward. Hurts especially when he does get some VA but it is never used that much.

- Story often feels insultingly lacking in subtlety, either spells out twists to the player too easily and/or makes them so obvious the characters look stupid

- Morgana is presented as an annoying, self-important moron throughout the story and when the story ends he is still an annoying, self-important moron. The game expects you to care about this.

- The dubbing feels kind of middling in places (but still good overall). Many of the lines feel way too overacted (especially Ryuji and Ann) to the point where it can be difficult to follow the story seriously.

- Many of the humor comes off as very out of touch and painfully bad, most notably the many involving sexualizing minors. The game seems to expect you to laugh at people lusting for underage girls/boys in several occasions and it comes off as extremely creepy on the writers' part and not funny at all. Aside from that there are of course many nonsexual jokes that don't land such as Morgana makes Ryuji mad for the 900 billionth time (because it was so funny the first time thank you Atlus).

- While a few unique mechanics spice up the battles a fair bit, the game still requires and is cheesable through level grinding which make these moments of engagement rare. Boss fights also largely negate elemental weaknesses and status effects for balance which cut out a fair bit of depth and make them more about being bullet sponges and stockpiling items

- The game wastes a lot of time going through menus and doesn't feel all that streamlined for the amount of repetition it expects out of you

- Items can feel like a chore to sort through, especially when labels are not informative or information on what an item does is completely absent aside from its name (skill cards).

- Elemental weaknesses being trial and error can be helped through some confidants which is okay I guess, although I'm not a fan of weaknesses being forgot after a failed battle against an enemy and coming back to them especially with the sheer amount of different enemies and elemental types.

- Needing to constantly check weaknesses on opponents if you can't keep track gets annoying with Makoto repeating her voice lines over and over again.

Good game tho do play

148531825.review:
One of the best games ever made!

It's like there was a rule during development 'everything has to be fun'.
Menu animations, transitions between locations, even the vendors - each shop has it's own theme song and style.

Fantastic music, every single piece is catchy.

And on top of that - the best turn based combat system I have ever seen in my life.
Combat is fast, incredibly satisfying to pull off combos, and they actually use the camera!
There's almost never more than 5 enemies in any fight, so you never have the fallout 2 issue of waiting for a rat 100 yards away to take it's turn.

The only possible downside is the story can get convoluted at times, and cycling through 100 items to see if any of them cure the 1 specific ailment you need is kind of bad.

But still, as someone who grew up on town-down CRPGs (Icewind dale, neverwinter nights, etc), where dialogue just has a portrait of a guy looking at you from 5 feet away, having characters move their face when talking and having different sprites for happy / angry expressions is already more than I've seen anywhere else.

On top of that - around 150 hours of STORY. There's (Almost) no grinding, just straight up an interesting story and so much of it.
This is what I always wished RPGs were like. I just never knew this game existed before.

So much of this game had me yelling 'why isn't every game doing this?' .

148512468.review:
Persona 5 Royal has captivated my imagination from the very outset, leaving an enduring impression. The game seamlessly weaves profound psychological intricacies into its captivating narrative, but what truly distinguishes it is its [b]masterful game design[/b].

One of the most remarkable aspects of Persona 5 Royal is its awesome ability to foster a profound connection with each character. Meeting, interacting with, and sharing their joys and sorrows made them feel like lifelong companions. The characters' emotional depth is astonishing, evoking a genuine empathy as if they were cherished friends. I became [b]deeply invested[/b] in their lives.

The game's narrative is nothing short of a [b]"magnum opus"[/b]! Every chapter and plot twist is spellbinding, compelling players to contemplate moral dilemmas and choices alongside the characters. It's a tale of justice and freedom, brimming with inner conflicts and authentic emotions. Playing Persona 5 Royal feels less like gaming and more like inhabiting the lives of these characters.

The game's presentation, encompassing visual aesthetics and user interface, impeccably integrates turn-based combat with real-life simulation. The meticulous attention to detail is evident not only in the menus but also in the stylish character designs and the intricacies of the Metaverse. This level of artistry and craftsmanship is a rare gem in the gaming world.

From uncovering the mysteries of the Palace of Cognitions to nurturing relationships with the characters and fighting for the hearts of the people, Persona 5 Royal challenges players emotionally and morally, imparting values of friendship, loyalty, and the pursuit of one's beliefs.

In conclusion, [b]Persona 5 Royal is an unadulterated masterpiece deserving the highest acclaim[/b]. It distinguishes itself as one of the greatest games ever created, leaving an indelible impression on players through its impassioned storytelling, captivating adventures, and the exceptional artistry of its game design.

148441486.review:
[h2]My honest thoughts after 1000+ hours: [/h2]

Replaying this game a dozen of times made me realise how average the story is, how cringeworthy most of the main characters are, how forgettable and generic the villains are (except for Kamoshida and [spoiler]Maruki[/spoiler]), and most importantly just how boring at times the dungeon crawling can be due to how extremely easy the game is even on the highest difficulty.

Yet despite its flaws, Persona 5 Royal is still one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. While the Phantom Thieves could have been written much better, this game has some of the most interesting side characters in the franchise imo. Characters like Iwai, Sojiro, Kawakami, and Maruki honestly carry the game. The soundtrack slaps, the UI and art style is beautiful, voice acting is perfect, and the gameplay is objectively the best in the franchise. Palaces are a massive improvement over P4 dungeons, and there are way more side activities you can do than in any other Persona game. 

Not only is this my favourite Persona game, it is my favourite game of all time. Even though it's flawed, I'm sure you'll still have a very good time with it on your first playthrough. If you would want to replay it numerous times, I recommend you do so with mods, at least the ones that completely rework the difficulty. Either way, if you're at least a tiny bit interested in P5R, then go for it and buy the game now. I 100% recommend it and honestly, most of the problems this game has are only really noticeable if you are mentally deranged just like me and put over 1K hours into this damn singleplayer game lol.

tl;dr game so good I haven't touched grass in months 👍

148358055.review:
Fool Labellin drifts through sensuous alleyways in search of his pen. The detached fugitive simply wishes to partake in the local merriment, indulging in bathhouse steam and medicinal stupor. And yet, few temporal seams are unimpeded by babble and burden. Behind his faint muttering and blank peering is a masked rage. The prattling of Mango, Ramen Sadsack, Itchy Ozone, Hamhair Okra, Yucky Mushroom, Chihuahua Muff, and Yugyug - most dreadfully Yugyug - corrode his sanity.

Twin rapscallions berate him as he absorbs remnants of executed obscenities. A tyrant in a pink thong hurtles spheres at him. Denizens morph into machines in a mendacious fantasy. Zealots attempt to transform existence via a network of violence, tunneling terror under the metropolis. There are two of him, and perhaps the other is more laudable. The ink as he writes this bleeds slightly with each stroke. But the lecher hides him, the recluse inspires, the gecko arms, the conjurer doses, and the schism seduces.

Where have they been? He's been searching all along, lacing the moonlight without any glue. The real question is where has he been? He's a shoeshiner, at the last parade, binding both space and time. What else should he be? In moments of aplomb, there's nothing left to be found. Except next to a mirror, he finds an empty glass, reflecting a sad truth - he's just a cage of bones. Don't celebrate the demise.

However, there is escape in a cozy attic. In bed, his head rests upon his hands as he's stargazing at the blemishes of the wooden rafters and plastered ceiling. Warmth from the kitchen below nudges a cool breeze from an open window into a puff of wintry mist. Twilight saunters in the streets below, echoing comfortably as he inhales the aroma of curry and coffee.

148322093.review:
[h1]It seems this is the limit of humanity[/h1]
After years of wanting to play [b]Persona 5 Royal (P5R)[/b], [b]Atlus[/b] finally made the game available for PC and it’s by far the longest turn-based [b]JRPG[/b] I have played. There is so much content for me to cover, and I don’t think this review will do this game justice on how much there is available.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]A fantastic story that will teach you the meaning of freedom
[*]Great characters that have impressive development and personality
[*]Fun turn-based combat with many unique abilities
[*]Lots of stuff to do in the overworld
[*]Awesome soundtrack that is just nice to listen to
[*]Beautiful graphics and unique style to the visuals
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]The dialog is a bit weird during the cutscenes
[*]Getting the best ending in the game is a bit cumbersome
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story starts out with [b]Ren Amamiya[/b] (you can change his name) who was falsely accused of assault one night when trying to defend a woman. He is then labeled a criminal and is now on probation as well as sent to [b]Sujin Academy[/b] where he will continue his second year of High School. He moves into the attic at [b]Cafe Leblanc[/b] thanks to the help of [b]Sojiro Sakura[/b] who is taking care of him for his probation period. He also gets his first new friend at his new high school who goes by the name of [b]Ryuji Sakamoto[/b].

That is all I will go into for the story of P5R, there is a lot for me to talk about and it would take at least half of this review to even talk about the beginning portion of the game. The story is just outright fantastic, and the characters shined greatly. They made the story just outright fun, with my three favorites being Ryuji Sakamoto, Yusuke Kitagawa, and Goro Akechi. I liked their personalities and how they all go along. There are other characters I liked as well but those three shined to me the most. I could make an entire review on the characters alone for the game, as there is just so much to talk about with them and the story.

The only issue I had with the story is how some of the dialog is presented in the game. This mainly stems from the English dub. There are times when characters will say "this means in English" while speaking English; I know they are in Japan but it just sounds awkward. I don’t mind if the dialog is changed in English dubs a tad bit and this is coming from someone who does prefer their subs over dubs. I was just too used to playing the Persona games in English when I started with P4G. This is, of course, my opinion only and you can play the game in whatever language you prefer.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay for [b]P5R[/b] is probably one of the hardest things for me to explain in this review as there is so much to talk about. However, I will go over combat first as that is the main gameplay feature of the game. In combat, you and your party members will have a certain [b]Persona[/b] with their own abilities, as well as a weakness to another ability. This also applies to the enemies that you will encounter as well. If you, a party member, enemy, or boss exploit a weakness, they will get an extra turn to do whatever they want. 

However, new to [b]P5[/b] (as this feature was in the original version) is the [b]Baton Pass[/b] feature, which allows a party member who exploited a weakness to allow a different party member to attack. This can be useful in some battles if different enemies have different weaknesses, so if one enemy is weak to ice and the other to wind and you have two party members or if [b]Joker[/b] (who is [b]Ren Amamiya[/b]} has a [b]Persona[/b] who can cover those weaknesses and already had his turn. The [b]Baton Pass[/b] mechanic is a handy feature that I recommend you take advantage of. You can also get some extra benefits from [b]Baton Passing[/b] as well, like restoring some HP, SP, and doing extra damage. However, you do need to hang out with your party members to get these benefits.

During combat, [b]Joker’s Personas[/b] will stop learning moves, what you can do then is go to Igor, who will then fuse your unwanted [b]Personas[/b] into new and more powerful ones. You can get new [b]Personas[/b] after battle but the method of getting them is different. [b]Shuffle Time[/b] has been removed and now you need to try and talk your way to understand the enemy and if both of your responses go along with what the enemy is feeling, you get a new [b]Persona[/b].

If you knock all the enemies down in combat, then you can do these [b]All-Out Attacks[/b]. These attacks will damage all enemies while doing physical damage, this will bypass physical immunity or resistance if the enemy has it. 

However, there is lots of stuff for you to do outside of combat, you can spend time together with your party members or other friends. This will increase your [b]social links[/b], which can be used for helping give the [b]Personas[/b] you fuse extra levels and experience, which will make them stronger than usual and they may learn a few extra useful moves as well. Your party members will also learn new abilities in combat that will help you out in certain situations, so I highly recommend you go out and hang out with everyone as much as you can.

You will also get requests to help other people out in [b]Mementos[/b], this is another area of the game that you can use to farm your [b]Personas[/b] and party members. I also recommend doing these as you can get some nice rewards when exploring the place which can be very useful in combat. Your party members will also have some conversations sometimes with each other that add to their character altogether.

Although, I do have one issue with the game and that is the method of getting the true ending of the game, which is entirely unique to [b]P5R[/b]. To get this ending, you need to max out three social links in the game and to add to this [b]Goro Akechi’s[/b] social does not progress in the story like in the original [b]P5[/b], you must hang out with him. All of these have a time limit, but the game gives you more than enough time to get all three of them maxed out, so there is that. It’s still cumbersome to do though, as you can’t really miss a day to hang out with at least two of them. One of the [b]social links[/b] you can max out with no issue as it’s small and that character is also unique to [b]P5R[/b] but the other two you must hang out with when they call you. This is not a big issue but something that still annoyed me, nonetheless.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The soundtrack for [b]P5R[/b] is honestly one of the best things of the game, every song I listened to was just fantastic and I loved them all. My favorites have to be [b]Life Will Change, Rivers In The Desert, Take Over, Last Surprise[/b], and [b]Ark[/b]. As you can tell, that is a long list of my favorite songs in the game, they are all honesty great.

[h1]Graphics and Performance[/h1]
[b]P5R[/b] is a beautiful game both in its 2D and 3D art style, I loved looking at all of the games areas it has to offer. I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50 and 16 GB of RAM. I experienced no issues while playing which ran at a smooth 60 FPS.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3051310040
[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
If you are looking for a great turn-based [b]JRPG[/b] with a lot of depth and obvious care from the developer, then I highly recommend [b]P5R[/b]. There is a lot to do in the title and this review does not do the game justice, at best, I have only talked about at least 10% of the game itself and it’s only because I can only fit so much into a review without risk of spoiling the story. If you want to uncover what this game has to offer, the only thing I recommend is to play the game yourself.

[quote]Unexpected situations are necessary at [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/5297658/]Life Needs a Little Sin [/url] after all[/quote]

148257407.review:
Get it on sale if you are REALLY need to play this rerelease, but in short:
— Game is made laughably easy by "balance" changes (you no longer have to ration your SP, they throw items at you, Mementos grinding was made brainless by Jose or whatever the kid's name was, allowing me to get a million yen in the first 1/3'rd of the game (still had 80% SP on my whole team, and I effectively have infinite money, it's just a choice on whether or not I want to waste X hours seeing the number go up)).
— Story is still laughably bad, feels like a rough draft more than a finished product; all the story points are seen a mile away unless you're high or just turning your brain off to mindlessly see number go up during lock-down fusions.
— Morgana.
— Had to fiddle with the graphics to get it to a point where it didn't make my eyes hurt from the blur (had to set it to %200 upscale, which is just laughable on its own), otherwise the graphics look passable to good.
— For a game that is carried by its cast, a lot of the actual dialogue choices you make actually don't matter, or they influence how many social points you get towards a Confidant's rank (and some of these perhaps don't translate well, but a number of the Confidant choices feel like they're either awkward or just saying what the other person wants to hear rather than what they want to hear, which isn't exactly what a good friend is or would say; a guide is recommended if you don't want to get shafted by arbitrary "You picked the dialogue option asking for more information instead of the one that just says "Yes!", so you're going to need to waste a timeslot hanging out with them, OR spend money at Chihaya's to increase the Confidant rank that way).
— Too few battle songs, you'll hear the new Royal theme constantly, and never the old "You'll never SEE IT COMMMIIIIN~!" 
— None of the main cast really feel like friends, just beings of (heavily contrived) circumstance that must work together; compare to the gang of the earlier Persona 4, where there was good chemistry there that inspires fanart to this day.
— The dub is atrocious and had me switch off it immediately; this is always a constant and goes without saying, but use subs. Though I also feel as if the localisers did their usual butchery (Futaba saying "KEK!" and various slang put here and there that just does not match the tone or vibes, IE the Phantom Website comments that sound like something a CEO would say while drunkenly mimicking what "A little zoomer" would say on the 'net).
— Goro.
— Morgana.
—Okumura's Palace is still a slog to play, and, impressively enough, Fatlus made the boss fight substantially worse than in Vanilla (playtesters too expensive, small family company, plz understand; oh, and buy the $200 Persona 3: Reloaded Special Edition plz :)).
— Denuovo.
— Can't fast-forward through All-out Attack animations because lol (you're going to be seeing the animation probably a thousand times by the end of the game, as it's a long, long game with quite a bit of padding).
— Kasumi, the new character added in Royal, is literally just a poochie. When she's not on screen, and before she has a scene, the characters talk about "Woah, did you hear about that athletic honor student? She's so cute, think I have a shot with her?" and "She's so great!" When she does interact with your character, she's always kissing up to you for literally no reason (she's a very popular student, so shouldn't she be less willing to just be BEST FRIENDS with someone she just met? Much less one with the MC's current reputation upon meeting?).
— Morgana.

Like, if this is your first JRPG ever, or if you don't play games besides the top 10 on Twitch, then it's pretty great. But if you've played other SMT games, read VNs or novels with proper characterization, or just even browsed Pixiv for pics of cute girls, then there really isn't much here beyond the surface-level flash and style that this game offers, which, admittedly, it does have in spades. Wish I could be more positive about this, as it HAS potential, and it leaves me hungry for a more finished product, but playtesting and hiring a professional storyboard team is too expensive for poor old Fatlus (this game is seven years old and still being sold at full price).

147948735.review:
---{ Summary }---
Man, how do I summarize this? Known to be arguably one of the greatest RPGs of all time, and that isn't exaggerated at all. My first playthrough, on Merciless difficulty (Highest of the 5 options) took 120 hours, and that alone makes a 60$ game worth the price. The best part is, in those 120 hours there is constant content and pretty much nothing repetitive. There is, in fact, so much to do that I found myself struggling to decide on what I would spend my days doing, and even with all those options, I later found out I had missed a TON of stuff, and I there were some confidants (people you can befriend, essentially) I never even talked to! I DEFINITELY recommend this game, it's visually amazing, the soundtrack is perfect, the gameplay is superb, the story is awesome, and the characters tie it all together in one excellent game. Get this game. Now. Stop reading my review and just play it.

---{ Graphics }---
While everything is a bit outdated and everything is sorta low poly/low res, something about the game is just beautiful. Maybe it's the retro-ish feel to it, maybe it's the talented people creating it, maybe it's that one Persona. Yeah, you know the one I'm talking about. No matter what it is, despite the PS3 graphics, it still looks amazing and definitely blows pretty much any other anime style game out of the water.

---{ Gameplay }---
The first thing that had me hooked when I started playing, aside from the opening scene of Joker in the Casino, and the scene where Kasumi is doing that weird dance fight thing, and... okay, maybe not the first thing, but ONE of the first things that had me hooked was when I was able to use guns. When I found out I could just shoot the crap out of anything with the push of a button, I just instantly got this rush of dopamine. It's just little things like that that make this game a joy to play. Yes, it is turn based, but something about the way that they do it makes it surprisingly immersive and fun. The soundtrack and sound design definitely help too. I normally get a bit bored in most turn based RPGs, just because of how boring most of them are. But this game definitely did it right. Outside of fighting, the system of just living your life is amazing. There is so much to do, and I know for a fact, despite me 130+ hour playtime, I've missed a ton of stuff. 

The best thing I can say to sell you on the gameplay is that within an hour of me finishing my first playthrough I started another so I could find some of the stuff I missed in my first time.

---{ Audio }---
Perfect. Best soundtrack ever. Need I say more? I guess so. The music is amazing, I don't think there is a single song I don't like on it (Though the one for the widely agreed upon worst Palace, which I won't name for spoilers, brings back bad memories, iykyk). I've tried both English and Japanese VOs and both are great. The only problem with the English version is their weird pronounciations of Japanese words. I heard that this was because of the voice director for the English version, which is definitely believable, the cast is filled with great talent and I know that they could've done it right. And I don't mean they pronounce it weird like saying words with an American accent (Like leaving the stressed R sound in, rather than the more subtle, almost silent version used in Japanese), I mean that they just plain pronounce words wrong. It's hard to describe in text form, and you probably wouldn't notice it if you didn't know much about Japanese, but it's just a bit odd at times.

---{ Can you run it? }---
The game does require surprisingly powerful hardware, despite it's age. I originally played on a much worse laptop which I used for gaming that had VERY outdated hardware (It had an i7-6600u for it's CPU and an R7 360 GPU, alongside a mechanical hard drive and only 8gbs of RAM). I could run it, but it struggled to hold 30 FPS on bare minimum graphics, 50% resolution scale, and playing on 720p. Now that I have a PC that actually works, I can run 4k resolution and max graphics with a solid 60 FPS.


(My Specs: 
GPU: Quadro RTX 4000
CPU: I7-9750H
RAM: 64GBs)

---{ Will I rage quit? }---
I played on the hardest difficulty and it was never too difficult. Sometimes I would need to plan a fight out a bit more than usual, but it's nothing a little brain power couldn't handle.

---{ Must I grind? }---
A little bit. There is a grind to pretty much everything, but they disguise the grind with fun gameplay and all sorts of things to keep you entertained. In my opinion, it's a grind, but it's a really fun one.

---{ Will the story replace my life? }---
Yes. I won't say more on account of spoilers, but yes. Yes it will.

---{ Is it worth the price? }---
Absolutely. You are getting hundreds of hours of content for only 60$, I've definitely spent more on stupider things. I used to play Fortnite after all.

---{ How buggy is it?}---
I have literally never seen a bug.

---{ ? / 10 }---

147867615.review:
Persona 5 The Royal (meaning the complete package/aka the "Definitive Edition") is one of those "almost perfect experiences". I've been playing this game since the original vanilla Persona 5 launched on PS4/PS3 and The Royal is an upgrade that makes a near-perfect turn-based JRPGs even greater. 
Yes, you need to be ready to deal with the turn-based system and yes, you need to balance and manage some sort of "social life simulator" system but don't let this strange-sounding combination fool you: What looks like it shouldn't work on paper, is actually brilliant. It also helps a great deal that ATLUS went all out on this and packed every nook and cranny of this game with amazing content. The dungeons are brilliant, the monster-collecting makes other monster tamer games blush with envy and the base mechanics of P5 are brilliant and assure that fights are quick and snappy. Couple this with a killer soundtrack, a stunning visual direction and (thankfully) every DLC they ever released in form of outfits/personas and what you get here is easily worth way more than the initial asking price.

Only downside: You need A LOT of free time to even attempt this game.
I'm also glad to report that the game runs smooth as butter on PC (which is sadly not the norm anymore).

10/10 - a really rare gem of a game.

147844716.review:
[h1]A Great Yet Flawed SMT Game[/h1]

Let me get this bit out of the way before I go heavily into detail for a TLDR: Do I think the game is worth playing? [b]Yes,[/b] especially if you find it on sale during a Sega or Atlus promotion. It's well worth the time investment if you're a fan of SMT games or turn-based RPGs. That being said... Do I think it's the greatest thing since sliced bread? Absolutely not. It's good, but caught on it's own leash. There will be spoilers, but they'll be marked.

[h2]The Good Bits[/h2]

The game starts off at a pretty high note all things considered. It's a LOT faster to get into the gameplay than Persona 4 did, thank goodness. There's a number of improvements to the core gameplay that helps bridge elements from across the series together. I absolutely LOVE that the classic SMT demons are the Shadows now, just like they used to be back in Persona 1/2 and SMT if. It helps significantly to aid in memory and recognition rather than just color-swapped masked blobs and objects from 3/4, which I thought was a pretty significant downside to those games. The fact that you actually have to negotiate with the Shadows to recruit them like they are really demons, plus the commentary by them in battle, and the fact that they are no longer purely random in said negotiations are huge benefits to help bridge the gap between series. The Baton Pass mechanic further incentivizes identifying weaknesses by offering additional moves and decisions. Do you pass the baton to someone else, or double-dip for setup? The UI presentation is also very much improved upon and gives the game a unique style. A number of smaller quality-of-life improvements such as being able to save the game nearly anywhere in the real world and plenty of Safe Rooms helps you be able to pick up and play if you only want to burn a little bit of time for preparations, and is far better than having to go chase a bloody blue butterfly every day. The palaces offer actual constructed dungeons in a Persona game again rather than simply procedural-generated grids in voids, but Mementos does carry that side... 

[h2]The Bad Bits[/h2]

Persona 5 Royal seems to hate the idea of letting the player off the leash entirely. Significant chunks of the game will basically have you railroaded by plot devices or a certain unlikable cat and deny you the opportunity to pursue Social Links or dungeon exploration. The Battle UI actually doesn't go far enough with showing who goes next unless you press on the D-Pad, and we're still in that weird Persona slant where buffs and debuffs are three-turn and single-target only unless you got 'Ma' versions. There's two new elements in Nuke and Psychic, but in practice, there's nothing interesting with them beyond just needing a unique element to tie to party members. This wouldn't bother me except that they already split Light and Dark into both offense/instakill at the same time so Nuke/Psychic just feel like pure filler as a result. In terms of balance, the game likes to 'try' to be difficult (especially if you play on Hard, did two playthroughs on Normal/Hard to compare) but also keeps fudging it's rolls for the player. Showtime moves, your Support interjecting, multiple fully-automatic Social Links and the Royal content all seem to act more like a helicopter parent yanking you away from scraping your knee up and learning your lesson through a bit of trial and error. It doesn't help that while you can ignore the Showtime button, a bunch of other things are basically automatically triggered without your inputs. Oh, and speaking of the Royal content....

[h2]The Royal Mess[/h2]

This is where we get kind of finnicky, and this entire section is probably going to be marked with spoilers to the point of impersonating some top-secret documents through this stint.

[spoiler]I really do not like the Royal content additions much at all. Let's start with the super intrusive type, and that's literally how intrusive and off-fitting the Royal additions feel. The characters of Royal, along with their scenarios, certainly feel very 'Atlus expansion re-release' in execution. What do I mean by that? I mean having the new stuff jutting out or shoved in haphazardly with lots of neon arrow signs pointing at them. Kasumi in particular gets it BAD with how she's not only shoved into the the intro scenario for little reason or impact but the game pretends it's a big moment, but also the character in general. Way too peppy and cheery, only to have that script flipped only in the tail end, but with no hints of that darker depths at all. I mean, come on, she got a bloody magical girl transformation. The Final Palace actually does have my interest as one of my favorites due to the unique puzzles, such as having to do a personality quiz from the mentality of your adversary rather than yourself. But at the same time, it feels wonky, especially in balance. Hell, ask anyone who completed the game and they'd probably tell you the finale was more cutscene than boss. There's also some seriously overtuned Personas introduced (why you can get them for free in the Compendium?) and all of the bonus costumes are also tied to a huge item bundle that screws up the start of the game. 100k yen plus like 20 Homunculus? And on that subject of costumes, while it is nice that you can dress up in the style of your favorite Persona/SMT games for the most part with different BGMs from said games... You cannot play said battle BGMs unless you are wearing that specific outfit on your protagonist. Really? There couldn't be an option to shuffle or set them independently?[/spoiler]

In conclusion, it's well worth it if you find this game on sale, and perhaps even at full price if you're a real sucker for RPGs or the Atlus brand. But just be aware that this game is not the pure and perfect game that people often rave it is. It's got some problems that set me off in particular, but I still enjoyed it nonetheless.

147793113.review:
An experience to remember. A playable anime. A benchmark for JRPGs and turn-based games. A 100+ hours journey into changing the hearts of the wicked and yourselves. 

Takes place over a bit more than a full school year, and lets you mostly decide what you do with your free time. Will you bond with a certain character, work a part-time job, fulfill people's requests, improve your social stats... It may seem repetitive at first and I can say that it is after a long time playing, but the game makes sure to relieve you of it with story beats and events. It also lets you move forward quite fast if you so desire. I fancy that the game lets you choose and asks you to put time into planning what you want to do, who you want to focus on... This is the best school-anime out there. 

The story and the characters are one in the same, and the central pillar of the game. The characters are all so charismatic and unique. You grow very attached to them over such a long exposure time. The game has such fantastic vibes to it. The UI and its transitions are splendid (it's cool to navigate the menus and the in-game UI is amazing too), the game is full of colour and personality. This eccentric personality is present in everything you see and do, from the story to the characters to the gameplay to the UI to the music... 

Special mention to the music too, deserves an award. Jazz-voiced tracks make the game feel so much better and are truly key in creating unforgettable moments. I can't stop listening to the OST. It's unreal how good the music and SFX are.  

Gameplay-wise, I love the staging. 4 characters with their personas, with proper animations, camera angles and voiceover to accompany their actions. Hell, just hearing Ryuji shout "PERSONAAAAA" during one of the main boss fights with amazing background music is already a treat to my senses. The weakness, technical, ailments and stats system is broad but simple to understand. I love the inclusion of many support skills and specially the baton pass, it's such a great mechanic and hypes you up. The showtimes are such a nice treat too, I loved Ann/Morgana, Ryuji/Yusuke and Joker/Akechi showtimes. There are also a bunch of chance-based events that help break monotony. 

The idea of Joker having multiple personas and being able to fuse them to obtain more powerful ones with shared abilities is super cool. I really enjoyed gathering personas to see what I could obtain. Having multiple personas allows you to plan your deck and make sure you have abilities for all situations. Feels like Pokemon in that regard.

The story is super interesting and mysterious. The moment of truth is so good it reminds me of Detective Conan's "The Clash of Red and Black" arc. It was most likely the best and most intricate arc in the whole series. The sheer amount of details was mind-blowing, and the same can be said for this game.   From that point forward, it is a non-stop rollercoaster. Full of memorable moments and charged with emotions.

It was sad to let go and say goodbye to the characters. The game is super long (100 hours) and this is both a liability and a strength. It amplifies emotions and exposure which helps bonding with the world/story/characters but at the same time it took me a month to play. Could it be trimmed somehow? Would it lose part of its charm? Maybe, guess I'll never know.

Such a long review and I still think I'm missing stuff. This is a must-play, take it easy and don't try to rush it, it will make for one hell of an experience. 

Sayonara Kokoro no Kaitou-dan

Si bien el juego te brinda una excelente historia y unos personajes fantasticos tambien en jugabilidad es bastante comodo y no tiene ningun sistema que lo haga tedioso, tambien para los que no estan familiarizados con este tipo de juegos es muy buena opcion empezar por este juego y abrirte mas a los Shin Megami Tensei aunque este sea el mas moderno tambien los antiguos son unos excelentes juegos que algunos incluso superan a esta entrega en mi opinion

Algo que no me gusto a diferencia de las anteriores entregas se nota que han bajado la dificultad, si bien aqui aunque estes en la pelea final y vayas en dificultad dificil y no hallas conseguido las mejores Personas no va ser tan complicado, en lo personal se te puede dificultar este juego solo si eres un pelotudo aunque esto no influye en que sea aburrido es totalmente lo contrario

Puntos positivos:

147722335.review: I won't lie i love everything about this game, the art style, the gameplay, and the fucking music is absolutely a treat to listen to. That being said the story isn't the greatest and is kinda bear bones in depth of characters if you don't do the optional character confidants. The confidants though in my opinion are some of the worst parts of the game, first off one of them is genuinely atrocious while some are bland or just too far into the story to actually get the character fleshed out. Second off they take up so much of your play time if you try to do them all it genuinely feels like a hassle or an inconvenience if their reward isn't good enough; not to mention some of them are just weird. Those are some of my only complaints for the game, the art style is extremely pleasing to the eyes and I could stare at it for hours. The gameplay is so good it's almost worth waiting so many hours at a time to play the game again. That is my biggest complaint for the game is that in-between actually rpg gameplay P5 likes to take it's sweet fucking time. I have probably spent up to 10 or more hours not actually playing the rpg part of the rpg that i spent $60 for, if that sounds that something that you wouldn't like in a game then you should not get this game, if you don't think you would mind it then go ahead and buy it. I genuinely believe if you can get through those slogs then you could find an amazing rpg that will hopefully go into one of your favorites. I don't really feel like mentioning the music, some of the tracks are not good at all but most of are absolute jams that I would listen to any day of the week, even if you don't think you'd like the game just listen to the soundtrack, you won' be disappointed. Update 1: I've finally finished the True Ending. SPOILER BELOW, don't read if you don't want to spoil yourself. 

[spoiler] Man it was a ride, fighting Maruki was tough (at least for me), but it was satisfying. The message that our team carried and conveyed, especially to Maruki, moved me a lot. Maruki definitely had good intentions, or rather misguided(?) intentions on wanting to remove pain from everyone so that everyone becomes happy. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] Ultimately, this only still hides from the problem and avoids reality all together. The message that our crew conveyed when fighting Maruki was the one that really resonated  
 with me the most; out of all the boss fights. All the previous boss fights were, in some manner ,fighting against the injustice that adults that committed. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] But Maruki instead wants to alter reality to remove pain, which definitely is different from all other villains that we've faced before him. His intentions are good, but the methods are dubious at best, convoluted at worst. Our protagonists reject the reality that Maruki wants to impose on everyone, and ultimately, we overcame him in the end. The message that was conveyed in throughout the True Ending portion, was, TLDR: In the face of hardship, you still move forward. You don't shy away from the pain, you face it. Of course, you don't have to do this alone, there are others who will help and overcome it together with you.[/spoiler]

Overall, an excellent game. I would strongly recommend

Para mi el mejor JRPG que existe, vale cada maldita hora que le eches, es extenso pero merece la pena, el juego te divide bien las secciones para que no se te haga pesado, puedes ir jugando un poco cada día a mi me ha durado realmente 1 mes, sin aburrirme, cosa difícil cuando un juego se prolonga tanto dado que se me acaban pasando las ganas de jugar.

Esto es totalmente objetivo, es el mejor sistema de combate por turnos que existe, se mea en cualquier final fantasy o cualquier juego que tenga este sistema.

La música es increíble y aunque la hayas oído dos millones de veces ("take over") te hace querer escucharla incluso fuera del juego.

Los personajes.... que decir de ellos, llevas tantas horas hablando con ellos y eligiendo opciones que al final es como si los conocieses realmente, muy carismáticos todos con sus puntos buenos, son gente normal, ni héroes, ni elegidos, que han obtenido una facultad, la cual, han aprovechado para evolucionar y superar sus problemas.

La animación de MAPPA cuando toca es brutal, como siempre no defrauda.

Por último decir que el sistema de Personas es el mejor juego de pokémon que existe, que Akechi es un personaje brutal y que el final es perfecto, Maruki es otro personaje increíble y alrededor de todo el juego tratan temas muy adultos, complejos y reflexivos, todo lleno de matices y detalles que te hace querer descubrir e indagar más.

No me extiendo más, para mi uno de mis juegos favoritos y el mejor JRPG que he jugado hasta la fecha. 
Gracias por haber creado esta obra maestra.

I have played the original Persona 5 on the PlayStation 3 and it truly was an incredible game, easily top 3 my favorite games ever. However, after revisiting the series with Persona 5 Strikers in 2021 and this year with Persona 5 Royal... I cannot say how much a anime-style JRPG has changed my life. Sounds stupid, but this very series of games made me hold on to my real life friends even more. I couldn't wait to play this game, especially because I was busy with final exams when it released. But now I coudl play it freely.

Game-wise, I loved every single second of it. Even though it's the third time I did the story (P5 normal playthrough and NG+, alongside this one), I am not bored. Insane. The story is truly immersive, long, perfectly-paced and just overall a treat. The characters just seem so real to me, it truly felt I made some amazing friends, which made our departure in the end the more painful, but you know, don't be sad because it ended, be happy because it happened. P5R adds some spice to the bosses and combat, disabling the Reaper Flu Season glitch from the original, adding Jose in the Mementos for more rewarding grinding and also the third semester, the last chance to finish up some remaining confidants, as it's customary for remastered versions of Persona games.

I adore this game.
Oh and also Futaba Sakura is THE best girl, she's literally me.

147002049.review:
I've already played and beaten Persona 5 Royal on the PS4 twice, and even on the third playthrough, I'm still having a blast. Like the majority of other Persona games, Persona 5 Royal is an insanely great game, and I would highly recommend it to anyone. I cannot say much due to it being a story based game, so I'll just get right to the ratings:

Gameplay: 8.5/10 - The gameplay feels very engaging and fun, especially when you start learning some fun combos, and figure out the best ways to get yourself "1 more" over and over. The combat is fun, and the non-combat systems are also pretty nice.
Story: 9.5/10 - I am not saying anything aside from that I absolutely love this story.
Visuals: 9.5/10 - The visual style of Persona 5 Royal is amazing, style oozes from every corner, whether that be in the animations, the text boxes, or even just the current date, it has a very fluid style that is extremely pleasant to look at.
Music/Sound: 9.5/10 - Again, another aspect Persona 5 Royal nails, the music is amazing as usual for this franchise, very energetic and fun soundtrack mixed with more somber tracks when needed. The sound design is also really good as well, everything is clear, and everything just works! Both the English and Japanese voices also are pretty nice, the Japanese voices are more consistent in being very good quality, but I have a soft spot for the English voices, which are still pretty good.
Replayability: 6/10 - Now this is potentially Persona 5 Royal's big issue, and is an issue with Persona in general which can't really be avoided, it's a story focused game that doesn't end up offering the kind of big changes you would find in different routes in games that are more VN focused. You can have fun replaying the game, due to the existence of New Game Plus, as well as being able to set yourself challenges, you can focus on building the best team possible, all that sorta stuff, however, this game is really damn long, replaying it is likely not something a decent amount of players would want to do, but that's completely fine when you consider that replayability is not the point.
Overall: 9.5/10 - I still believe Persona 5 Royal is one of the best games to be released in general, and is definently my favourite game of all time as of writing, it executes everything it's aiming for really well, and is a blast to play.

Without realizing, Persona 5 became a huge part of my life, or at least most of my 20s. I played this game day one on PS4 back in 2016, loved it so much I did a second playthrough. I played Royal when it originally released in 2020 during the start of the covid lockdown and now finally on PC.

Throughout the years since its 2017 NA release, I have written reviews and lengthy blog/forum posts on why I love Persona 5 so much. It’s one of my all time favorite video games for a reason. Despite its many, many writing, pacing, and repeated expository dialogue, there’s just nothing else like it.

I cannot understate the impact this game has had on me. Whether it’s to become a better artist, to achieve something that’s even close to what this game makes me feel, or standing up on my two feet and changing the world even when it’s tough, I can say Persona 5 helped me in some way, as corny as it sounds.

I love this game. That’s really all I can say.

There's no autosave, you can't open menus in dialogue or combat, repetitive combat cutscenes can rarely be skipped. I feel like 30% of this game is learning how to enjoy it around all it's nonsensical oversights, a lot of frustration that could have very easily been avoided. 

JRPG fans seem to like it, but I feel like you could ask for so so so much more from a JRPG at this steep price tag. As a visual novel it's enjoyable, under the pattern of:
- These characters are annoying but they make Joker look good
- Joker doesn't have many lines so they feel more important
- Everybody likes Joker or is intentionally written to be disagreeable
Given the quantity of writing it all seems to be pretty good and consistent.
