146723092.review:
I just beat Persona 5 Royal for the first time, including the True Ending. I've played a good handful of jrpgs: Earthbound, Xenoblade Chronicles, Pokemon (if you can count that), Dragon Quest, and this game stomps them all. It's a JRPG for people who are averse to JRPGs. It's got an amazing setting that isn't just "generic fantasy rpg", it's got lovable characters, an amazing story, and the battle system isn't boring or makes you wanna rip your hair out. This game has taken over my life and changed me for the better. 

It's not a perfect game by any means. There's some yikesy moments, especially when it comes to sexualizing the cast of minors and being able to date adults as a minor, the story takes a few dips sometimes, and the protagonist is the generic perfect badass male hero that gets all the ladies. But I still don't think that it detracts from the overall experience. It's an amazing game, and when it's at it's peak, and Life Will Change starts playing, no game has yet to top that feeling for me. Just pure HYPE!

I love this game to death. It is a masterpiece, and I will recommend this game forever. I would recommend getting the True ending as it adds another story arc to the game and, in my opinion, is the only valid ending for this game. What they added in Royal truly elevates P5 as like a 7.5/10 to a 9.5/10 for me.

Oh, and this isn't Pokemon, use buff and debuff moves. I didn't know that until really late in the game and it is literally a game changer.

Bought this game on sale and it's absolutely worth it. This game oozes both style and substance. This is a great entry point for people looking to get into the Persona franchise. 

The visuals are such eye candy and the way they designed the world to feel lived in without killing your PC is smart. Every enemy encounter is engaging and satisfying with all the visual flourish while still having a good amount of depth to the combat mechanics.

Music is superb with its jazzy funky vibe. It elevates combat encounters to make them feel more engaging, it brings intensity to the serious moments, and it provides a sense of catharsis in its more quiet, peaceful moments.

I've been a long time Persona fan, and a fan of the greater Shin Megami Tensei family of games, and I would wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone, fan or not.

146530131.review:
Before playing Persona 5 Royal, I'd already played the original Persona 5. Even just the vanilla P5 is one of the greatest RPGs of all time, with a cast of lovable characters, incredible visual style and soundtrack, and hours upon hours of content, not to mention the most fun the Persona gameplay has ever been. 

One could think it would be boring to replay the same game with just some changes again. Well, thankfully, Royal manages to make it work. Even the content from the vanilla game is enhanced, between the re-done Akechi confidant, and adding Maruki and Yoshizawa into the original game's events, not to mention adding follow-up conversations to all original confidants. On top of that, hunting for Will Seeds in the Palaces, Jose's stamps in Mementos, and the dart minigame add a lot on the gameplay front, and make it fun even if you've played the original.

Then, there is the third semester. I think it's an amazing addition to the story, showing a situation the Phantom Thieves have not faced before - trying to change the heart of an adult who doesn't have evil intentions. I can't say he doesn't have selfish intentions, because it does feel like creating a new, pain-free reality is some way to feed his savior complex... but the last palace's ruler does not wish to exploit people, only to help them, even if it's in a way not everyone would agree with, that takes away their agency. I think it's really interesting to actually have the Phantom Thieves question their morality, doubt if they're doing the right thing. Is freedom worth more than happiness? Aren't the struggles we overcome a part of what defines us? It adds on to the already brilliant story of P5 in a very satisfying and constructive way, making Royal, at least imo, the definitive P5 experience.

P5R is, without a doubt, one of the best games I've had the pleasure of playing, and I'm planning at some point to go back and do NG+, just to try and complete everything there is to do in this masterpiece of an RPG.

Currently loving this game a lot more than i thought it would 

First off, the music gets you into it almost immediately. I've always believed that music can make or break an experience. For example, the music of The Last of Us is haunting. Whether it's the solo guitar that plays that makes it feel like you're alone in the world, or the heavy orchestral music during certain scenes. That music makes the game, because if the music was switched out for some heavy metal or pop punk, the game just wouldn't work at all

I don't know what to call the music of this game. Is it jazz? is it funk? Is some of it rock? definitely, but there's one overlaying theme. It all fits, seamlessly

I've not finished the game, but it's already one of my favorite games of all time. The world building, the characters, the dialogue, the story, the TWISTS. My god, this game has certain misdirections, certain twists in story that you wouldn't expect, and they end up blowing your mind

146390547.review:
Amazing game that’s super addicting. Great story with an incredibly strong cast of characters. The English voice overs are really well done, some of the best I’ve seen from a JRPG. It left me wishing more scenes were fully voiced.

The game is quite long but never really feels like it’s too bloated like some more modern long games, however there were times near the end of the game I was ready for it to finish as some arcs aren’t as strong as others and drag on.

The post game Royal content/third semester is great fun though, it has a great start that draws you in right away and features the best antagonist of the entire game. It’s well worth getting to, and even though I was ready for the game to end just before the third semester started, when it kicked in any burnout I had from the long game was gone. I was ready for more thanks to the excellent third semester start serving as almost a palette cleanser.

The PC port is good with no major issues or frame drops. Pretty solid all the way through. Although, P5 is a game originally designed for the PS3 so it would be shocking if it came to PC in 2022 with issues. However, it does have a minor problem, the shadows reset to medium after every loading screen/transition, which means they will reset after minutes. Even though the settings menu continues showing it’s set to High, it won’t be. Luckily there’s a mod on gamebanana that fixes this issue, but it does mean having to install and launch the game through a mod launcher. Disappointing that the port got patches but this issue was never addressed. 

Even if you aren’t into JRPGs, or VNs, this game is an absolute must play. One of those games where once the credits roll you are left a little in awe.

146320337.review:
For those who didn't play Persona 5 in the Playstation I seriously recommend playing it if you like turn RPGs in general. The story is very good, the characters are very lovable and what it may drive away some people is the focus in things "outside" the main RPG gameplay (By that I mean the dungeons and the battles), things like social activities, a lot of dialogue in cutscenes, interactions with the many characters in the game, or increasing the MC stats to be able to progress with some social link or task. 

If you only want to explore dungeons and battle enemies, I think this game would drive you away from that for several hours (unless you skip all of the non related stuff), but if you like inmersion and enjoy watching a interesting story with sympathetic characters, you'll enjoy this as much as I did in my more than 100 hours. 

Also, when you understand the baton pass mechanic, the game becomes really easy too quick as it trivializes many battles, but that is as long as you know the weakness of you opponent, otherwise you'll be doing some trial and error before finding the easy way to deal with enemies.

145940663.review:
[b]DIsclaimer:[/b] if you made it to this page trying to decide whether to buy this game, go ahead. You are 96% likely to love it's story, music, characters, and combat just as much as everyone else in the world.
I, on the other hand, have a disorganized list of problems with this game that I hope can maybe fix future installments or warn particularly apprehensive buyers. I'll start with things I do like though, just to delay the notion that I hate-played this game just so I could hate it with more authority.
[b]The Good:[/b] 
- Most of the female characters are excellently designed and given engaging friendship/romance dialogue
- Takemi
- Futaba
- The stylized menus are cool
- The non-vocal BGM is mostly great, and the vocalist is also decent in some songs
- I appreciate that they cared enough to make an actual mini-game for the baseball and darts activities.
- I can't recall any performance issues I ran into
- It was easy for me to setup and use a controller. 
I thought I'd have more to talk about here. It really was the characters that got me this far. 


[b]The Bad:[/b]
- Morgana is a garbage character. I know everyone loves these mascots, but on top of being ugly as fuck in costume, it's also annoying as fuck and thankfully our own private Navi to narrate our life. I don't know it's secret and honestly don't care. 
- You cannot save whenever, so there are certain stretches of days that you just have to get through until you can actually save the game again. I'm not trying to save scum dialogue or something, I just wanna quit sometimes right when the game decides it's gonna be on autopilot for 3-4 days.
- Minor thing, but why are there only like 20 save slots? I ran out towards the end, so I now have to overwrite more saves. I initially split off to have checkpoints to go back to if something went south or I missed an achievement or something, but now I'm having to go back up the list and it's awkward.  
- The male characters were kind of annoying, except the doctor, Sojiro, and Akechi. Ryuji was just stupid, and it was annoying when that had consequences. Yusuke just never had any appeal to me, and his ignorance was not as amusing to me as it is to other people. Why did both of these fucks come to my house but never any uninvited girls? Fuck your "people watching" Yusuke
- On the topic of Morgana, they use this little shit to convey all these random restrictions on certain nights that make absolutely no sense. You just finished a palace or left mementos, you're too tired to go outside(I know there's a workaround later, but why should we even need it?). Some random story thing is happening tomorrow, let's go to sleep early. Sometimes they don't even let you do activities in your room, even though they gave you control of the character. I'm so glad it's MY decision to go immediately to bed because Morgana pulls some shit out of his ass when I try to interact with anything. Just make the day pass, like fucking seriously. 
- The main story has incredibly shitty writing. It feels like a sitcom, the way drama starts or conflict is created to push things along. Every new adversary has to manufacture some ticking clock that won't stop until like a day before it's over, even if you resolve the problem immediately. If you rush it, like it seems you canonically should, you just wait 20 days of group texts afterwards about how everyone hopes it works out. Glad I felt compelled to resolve a problem for a character I care about, only to have them wait out the timer to be saved anyways. Like, just let it end early and give me free time in the middle? Why is that so hard? I'm not going to complain about not having a time-bomb in the top right corner that I've already defused.
- This is apparently just a personal thing, but I really hate the vocal version of the song that plays every night. Like, especially the part where they say "I'm a shapeshifter". I know this is too much to ask, but I'd love to be able to disable certain songs or toggle what I would want to play instead. But you just get to change music volume, so I played a bit on mute to keep my brains off the wall a bit longer. 
Kinda same thing with the casino music vocals, but less exposure = less vitriol 
- Why didn't they make a pool/billiards mini-game. I feel so detached when I have no input/agency and just watch. 
- There were a lot of dialogue options that I didn't get any hearts for, despite it seeming like I was just being playful or making a joke. I hate feeling like I need to choose a different option than what I wanna say because I don't want to have to waste an evening later with a non-relationship enhancing encounter. Joker just has to be stereo-typically supportive all the time. 
- A lot of the Mementos quests are really unclear. How am I supposed to guess I need to work at the flower shop twice to get info or figure out that gamer one. 
- I initially expected getting a job to be more committal
- As much as I praised some of the relationships earlier, it sucks that they seem stuck to a formula of "introduce character that has conflict around rank 5 or 6 (maybe earlier) and then you have to go to mementos to fix them at rank 8 or 9. Like, maybe someone's problems in life aren't solved by factory resetting one or more demons in their life.
_______________________________________________________________________________
[b]Combat:[/b] Thought this deserved it's own section. I've not played other persona games, so this is not rated against them.  
- There is very little to go off of when trying to guess something weakness. There seems to be something about flying things being weak to guns/lightning/ice, but beyond that, I was mostly just trying everything until it worked. This wasn't satisfying at all, and just artificially extended combat encounters. 
- Stunned things do not lose their turn. This became particularly annoying during a certain palace boss, but it's really unsatisfying to be unable to stun everything in the first turn, so you just have to watch them all wake up and attack you one after the other. It feels like they should lose a turn recovering, and I would not mind if that was mirrored on the player. 
- Fusing is super unsatisfying. There's a chance that you can fuse your 2 level 50 personas and make like a level 5 fairy. I know it's not random, but why is that a thing? You can also fuse two things and the level is like 90, so you're like, cool, guess I'll just buy them back later. Why not balance this a bit more so things always/only get a bit stronger, proportional to the avg level of the two or something. Like your two level 50s combine to make 55 or 60, so you are likely to be able to make things you can actually make use of? There's barely a point for personas to even level up when they jumps are just better from fusing if you can get the right personas to fuse. 
- Bosses are just not fun. Most of them are just about surviving or stat checking you, which is not really strategic. 
- I'm gonna put this in combat, but why does walking around in palaces feel like a PS2 game? The platforming is so restrained and exploration is locked behind what glows. See a window that seems relevant? Wait till the story lets you go there because it's not important yet. Wanna jump down somewhere so you don't have to walk all the way around to the stairs and sneak past a bunch of enemy spam you don't wanna deal with? Too bad, you're a cripple when the wall isn't shiny. It just feels clunky to do anything. 
- I think the default difficulty should give a lot more damage for weakness hits and the finisher when everyone is stunned. This is mostly fine for groups, but it feels terrible against single target bosses/mini-bosses
- There should be something that tells you if a persona/boss is immune to a status. There doesn't seem to be any indicator or intuition for what will completely ignore everything, but I guess just don't bother trying to sleep bosses. 
_______________
I ran out of characters.

145669324.review:
Persona 5 Royal stands as a remarkable addition to the genre and a must-play for fans of the series. It not only pays homage to its predecessors but also excels in enhancing key elements. The game introduces depth to battles, leveling, and bonuses, offering a more immersive gameplay experience. The inclusion of personas from previous games adds a nostalgic touch. Moreover, the abundance of ways to acquire items and the distinct playstyles of companions further enrich the game's appeal.

One of the game's standout features is its player experience. Building social links with characters feels seamless and rewarding, often granting new abilities and unlocking fresh perspectives on gameplay. This fosters a sense of progression and encourages players to explore these connections, which are backed by well-crafted character development.

The game's narrative is a strong point, with a captivating beginning that sustains interest throughout. The thoughtfully designed characters become individuals you genuinely care about, evolving into familiar faces over the course of the adventure. The storytelling is peppered with surprising twists and turns, including the additional DLC content, which introduces compelling new characters.

The soundtrack is a mesmerizing auditory masterpiece, with each track contributing to the game's atmosphere seamlessly. Even the DLC-specific music, while distinct, serves a meaningful role within the storyline.

However, some aspects could be improved. The ending, while arguably designed to lead into future titles, feels somewhat abrupt. The decision to truncate the ending seems like an attempt to mitigate player frustration, although it may not have been necessary. Moreover, the "True Good Ending" lacks the depth and emotional resonance of its predecessor, with the game seemingly rushing to its conclusion. The missed opportunity for more meaningful character interactions in the closing moments is a letdown.

While avoiding spoilers, it's worth noting that there are some inconsistencies within the game's universe.

In conclusion, Persona 5 Royal deserves a solid 9/10 rating. It offers an exceptional gaming experience despite its flaws. Those who invest the time to fully immerse themselves in this lengthy adventure will undoubtedly find it a memorable and enjoyable journey.

[h1] ¿Qué es Persona 5 Royal? [/h1]

Se trata de la edición completa de Persona 5, que viene con el DLC Royal. Este nos aporta un nuevo semestre en la vida de los ladrones fantasma, que sin duda alguna, no deja indiferente a nadie.

Podemos jugar a Persona 5 sin conocer los anteriores, ni haber jugado a la saga en la que se basa (Shin Megami Tensei), aunque posiblemente sea más disfrutable de esa forma.

Consta con un combate por turnos con diferentes debilidades de los enemigos y un sistema de relevos bastante interesante, aunque quizás lo más destacable sean las interacciones sociales. Jóker (nuestro protagonista) será el que irá conociendo a distintos personajes, con los que establecerá vínculos que le permiten obtener ventaja en combate. Un sistema bastante entretenido, que nos mete de lleno en la historia y hace disfrutar aún más de las peleas.

Es posible perderse el contenido "Royal" por lo que, os recomiendo buscar una guía sin spoilers sobre cómo poder llegar a este contenido. 

[h1] ¿Merece la pena? [/h1]

Sin duda alguna, sí. 83 horas me ha llevado a mí completarlo al 100% de logros, aunque hay personas que tienen hasta 120 horas de contenido "non-stop". Otro trabajo más de ATLUS impecable.

8 hours in, and i've barley scratched the surface of the tutorial stuff.
I've always been curious about this game, seeing how it's always got these 10/10's everywhere and was rated so highly by everyone, so I went ahead and got it, going in blind.
Now I see why so many people love this game, even just with my short time playing.

Interesting story, deep-ish combat that i'm still trying to get a handle on, areas packed with goodies and secrets and stuff to find, and characters that just sorta grow on you.
Everyone's got their own personality and stakes in whats going on, and the dialogue is believable and nice to read, like the characters themselves. 
My only nitpick, if I had to point one out, is the acquisition of the 'powers' themselves. I feel like something got lost in translation, or that they assume you already know whats going on when the things erupt from your face the first time.
But, I mark that up as just "normal jrpg wierdness" that all of these games have.

If you're on the fence about this like I was for the longest time, i'd say just go ahead and nab it. Its fresh and interesting, with a LOT of stuff to see and do.

164h to completion. All 53 Achievements, 100% Persona Compendium, Errybody at Lv99, All Bonds maxed, All Stamps collected, erry place unlocked, erry movie watched, erry vidya game played, erry book read, Secret Mementos Boss defeated, etc

Coming from Persona 4 Golden, the game was pretty much better in almost erry possible way. From the prominent things such as the art/visual upgrade and the significantly better dungeon exploration and combatUI/animations, to minor things like animated sprites during cutscenes, and countless other QoL improvements. 5/10, rounded down to "not recommended", but I kinda neither recommend nor don't recommend it...
upd: just finished the third semester, just as I expected it is 90% full of bloated fillers. And omg, you cannot even skip the credits, I was on subway and almost failed to make a save due to those unskippable 10 minutes credits - luckily my deck survived at 3%... The devs definetely do not respect your time... Probably the most evil devs (or moe likely studio execs) I've ever supported with my coin, totally not gonna buy any more atlas games, unless someone finally steals their heart - go phantoms, I believe you can do it xD

My opinion - it's a flawed masterpiece... or maybe bloated masterpiece would be more accurate?

I started the game already having some niche expectations that didn't influence my evaluation:
- the game is over 100h long;
- the game is half jrpg and half Japanese school simulator;
- the game is not fully voiced and thus the characters will be making silly noises almost constantly;
- the game is completely linear, and your choices doesn't matter;
- time is the most important currency in the game.
I was aware that not everyone like such staff, and went i the game anyway, since it is something I'm Ok with. I also need to disclose that I'm suffering from perfectionism, but I believe that even if you skip the majority of the content(unlike me) you will still get annoyed by all the bloatware. Although, if you take long pauses and finish other games while playing the game, you might not mind it.

Overall the story is 8/10. sometimes it gets boring, but most of the time it plays just like the silly anime you expect it to be.

The character roaster is 6/10. Some of the main and side characters are completely boring, and their story better be integrated into other characters.

the side stories are 6/10. some of them are really interesting, maybe 9/10 or even 10/10, but majority of them are just bloated fillers. If I were the editor, I would've cut 30% of the party members and 30% of non battle confidants. But they probably just HAD to include more, since it is good for marketing...
Oh, yeah. even the good ones are bloated since writers had to make each confidant to have 10 events, it would've been nice if they cut it to 3-5. But hey, target audience like the game to have more hours, even if t makes the game bloated AF..

oh, yeah. the constant use of word pooped is def 0/10. it took me forever to realize they mean fucked. Worst low effort censorship ever...

the minigames are 5/10. there's way too many of them and they have too many levels/subgames. too many books/dvd/games as well...

Overall, If they cut 30% of the lazy bloated content from daily life, it would've made that part of the game perfect.

jrpg side is pretty good. 7/10. once again, I would've cut 30% of the map size and 30% of the puzzles to make it perfect. But as is it's pretty good.

combat is also alright, but gets easy as you learn the mechanics and progress in story. by mid game i've already switched to merciless difficulty but the battles were still very easy. luckily Riuji + hunting the reaper a few times allows you to RUN into enemies for insta-kills allowing you to skip most battles xD

Overall the game is good, but doesn't value your time. Cutting out the bloated parts of the daily life and half of the palaces would make the story more concise and the combat challenging till the end. but I guess 50h game is harder to sell to the target audience, that would much prefer bloated 150h game...

P.S the game runs fine on steam deck, but anti-aliasing suffers greatly, probably the didn't have 720p screens in mind when testing it or the engine just couldn't handle it and they decided to ignore it :( looks gorgeous at 1080p, though...

145351244.review:
I wanted to play this game for two reasons:
1) To see if its as great as everyone says,
2) Because I've been searching for a fun, challenging turn-based RPG.

I played the game on Hard difficulty, which I later found out is the hardest difficulty (Merciless is easier - google it). On Hard difficulty, this game's turn-based combat is exactly what I wanted. Boss battles are hard enough to force you to strategise, find the boss' weaknesses, and make use of your party's full moveset.
Of course, you can't mention "Persona 5" and "difficult boss" in the same sentence without mentioning 
[spoiler] Okumura [/spoiler] . This boss was brutal and often considered to be the hardest boss in the game by far. And this may be a hot take, but I LOVED it. I was stuck on this boss for an entire week and I even made an Excel spreadsheet to track my strategy. But if that's not your style, you can always lower the difficulty.

The other half of the game is the life-sim aspects. The Yakuza franchise has spoiled me for life-sim/side content, so this game doesn't quite hold the torch to it but it comes close. Persona 5's confidant system really expands on the main and side-characters and does wonders for worldbuilding. 
The calendar system is a unique and interesting mechanic, the likes of which is rarely seen in gaming. Because time passes only as a result of you doing activities (main or side content), the game simultaneously incentivizes you to engage in side content, yet restricts the amount of side content you can do. I never felt the dilemma of "Am I missing out on side content by rushing the story?" or vice versa, that I often feel with other games. Every day has a purpose, and unless there's a scheduled story event, it's up to you to decide what that purpose is.

All of this ties in beautifully with the story, which is not just about some high-schoolers with special powers, but about how those powers affect society as a whole. The game has excellent storytelling with plenty of mysteries that unfold throughout the game. The game focuses on several main villains whose motives aren't that far off from real life corrupt people in power. The game's palaces both literally and [i] literally [/i] give you a deep look into their minds and how they think.

This game really exceeded my expectations and I will be playing more SMT/Persona games in the future.

145333373.review:
Persona 5 Royal marked my introduction to the Persona series, and perhaps it will remain the pinnacle of my gaming experience within persona. Allow me to elucidate why this is the case.

I harbor a genuine affection for this game. It demanded 133 hours of my time to navigate its intricacies, and every moment was a delight. If I were to pinpoint a standout attribute, it would be the meticulous attention lavished upon even the minutest elements. The game's ability to sustain engagement throughout its considerable length is astonishing; monotony is conspicuously absent. Every facet serves a distinct purpose, ripe for utilization. Even a choice postponed by 40 hours could prove valuable at any given moment. On occasion, certain characters undertook actions that I had unlocked some time ago, prompting a surge of gratitude for the timely unfolding of events.

Furthermore, the overarching stylistic coherence merits praise. The game exudes a unique aesthetic across menus, the metaverse, and reality itself, thus amplifying the immersive quality of the experience. Notable examples include Jose's menu design, alongside the visually captivating menus of Iwai and Takemi.

The music is simply exceptional, leaving me in awe of the ingenious process behind crafting such an outstanding soundtrack. Each time I listen, a wave of shivers engulfs me, evoking the sensation of stealthily infiltrating various palaces while embodying the essence of a true Phantom Thief. Even during challenging battles, the soundtrack doesn't falter, delivering resounding masterpieces that are destined to etch themselves into my memory indefinitely. Without a doubt, this ranks among the most remarkable soundtracks in the realm of video games that I've ever had the privilege to experience.

The combat adheres to classic JRPG mechanics, offering an engaging and enjoyable experience. Admittedly, certain Personas possess overwhelming power, and particular boss encounters left me disenchanted due to a rather one-dimensional approach of endurance and methodical, gradual depletion of their health. These battles lacked the strategic depth present in encounters earlier in the game.

Returning to my initial point, I contend that Persona 5 Royal might stand as my sole foray into the Persona universe. In terms of style, narrative, and gameplay, no other installment appears to compare. This game seems to encapsulate the essence of the Persona formula flawlessly. While I acknowledge that others might hold differing viewpoints, I maintain that this sentiment reflects my personal assessment.

One more thing though Fuck You Okumura and your dogshit fight :)

Then of course there spending 15 days leveling up one stat just so you can go work on your confidants, and half the time you only raise 1 point in any category

The game has its pros, amazing visuals, great story lines, but its overshadowed by the tedium and the cringy jokes that, I found myself using the fast forward button very often.

Its obvious there was a lot of hard work put into this, but I find it hard to separate the art from the artist, when the peaks of cringe happen in game instead of just in reality

If this doesn't bother you however, the gameplay is very well designed, and the story, outside of some exceptions, is really great when you can get into it, just remember at times the story is gonna contain every other standard anime type cringe that you sometimes see, and the gameplay can get tedious and repetitive.

144859288.review:
Score: 10/10

Introduction:
Persona 5 is not just a game; it's a mesmerizing journey into the labyrinthine corridors of the human psyche, where vibrant aesthetics, unforgettable characters, and a complex narrative converge to create an opus that resonates deeply with players. Atlus has weaved an intricate tapestry of psychology, supernatural powers, and social simulation, resulting in a title that defies classification and stands as a pinnacle of interactive storytelling.

Visuals:
The visual design of Persona 5 is a living work of art that thrusts players into a vibrant and stylized Tokyo. From the strikingly animated menus to the meticulously crafted environments, every frame pulsates with a sense of purpose and style. The use of bold colors, intricate patterns, and unique character designs contributes to a world that feels both surreal and familiar, drawing players into its embrace.

Gameplay:
Persona 5's fusion of turn-based combat, social simulation, and dungeon exploration is a symphony of gameplay mechanics that harmonize effortlessly. The innovative "Confidant" system deepens character relationships and grants tangible benefits in battle, while the Persona negotiation and fusion mechanics add layers of strategy and customization. The time-management aspect of juggling school life and the supernatural imbues the experience with a sense of urgency and immersion.

Story and Characters:
Persona 5's narrative is a labyrinthine tapestry of psychological exploration, societal critique, and personal growth. The story tackles themes of rebellion, justice, and the masks people wear in an oppressive world. The main characters are multi-dimensional and endearing, each harboring secrets that gradually unfold through heart-wrenching confessions. The synergy between the narrative and character development creates an emotional resonance that is rare in gaming.

Soundtrack:
Shoji Meguro's soundtrack is an auditory masterpiece that enhances every facet of Persona 5. The eclectic mix of jazz, rock, and electronic genres captures the game's urban atmosphere and emotional depth. Memorable tracks like "Life Will Change" and "Rivers in the Desert" punctuate key moments with an energy that stays with players long after they've put down the controller.

Aesthetics and Themes:
Persona 5's aesthetic choices transcend the visual and auditory realms, seeping into its thematic core. The motif of masks, rebellion, and the "Metaverse" resonates on both a narrative and symbolic level, mirroring the personas people adopt to navigate their lives. This introspective exploration of identity adds layers of depth, inviting players to reflect on their own masks and motivations.

Longevity:
With a sprawling main storyline, hidden secrets, and multiple endings, Persona 5's longevity is practically boundless. The New Game+ feature encourages subsequent playthroughs, allowing players to carry over progress and unlock new interactions. The desire to uncover all confidant stories, fuse every Persona, and uncover the mysteries of the Metaverse ensures that the allure of Persona 5 never fades.

Conclusion:
Persona 5 stands as a magnum opus that marries its distinctive aesthetics, compelling characters, and layered gameplay into a transcendent experience. Atlus has achieved a feat of storytelling that transcends the medium, creating a masterpiece that lingers in the minds and hearts of players. With its evocative visuals, rich gameplay, and profound narrative, Persona 5 secures its place among the most treasured works of interactive artistry.

144665351.review:
[h1] PERSONA 5 TE HARÁ ODIAR A LOS GATOS [/h1]

[i] Sí... alguna vez leíste ese encabezado, ¿verdad? [/i]

Persona 5 Royal es el tercer juego de la saga Persona que me paso, segundo si solo contamos los juegos de la línea principal. Tengo sentimientos encontrados con este juego, siempre me decían que era una obra maestra y que era superior al 4. No, no lo es. Claro, solo la segunda afirmación porque es un JUEGAZO en toda la regla. Tal vez peca un poco en la historia y en los personajes, pero nada fuera de lo normal. En lo que sí estoy de acuerdo que le da una barrida al 4 es en el gameplay, aunque es lógico, ya que es un juego 8 años después (WTF Atlus, ya va a pasar 8 años desde que sacaste el 5, por favor ya saca el 6)

Dejando a un lado las comparativas y enfocándonos en otro punto. Persona 5 tiene los despertares más épicos que he visto hasta el momento, no los mejores, porque esos son los del 4 (otra comparativa, debió ser una sorpresa) me gusta mucho el tema de la rebeldía hacia la sociedad o los prejuicios, simplemente Atlus supo hacer bien este apartado, además de que cuentan con tremendo OST que con eso llegamos a otro punto.

Seré sincero, me siguen gustando más el ost de Persona 3 y Persona 4, pero tampoco es para rebajar a los temones de este juego (con decir que siempre los escucho al momento de jugar otro juego o al estudiar ya es mucho) 

En cuestiones de trama, pues, es lo que esperarías como mínimo de un jrpg. Está bien, pero no es la venida de Jesucristo. El cast principal es otro punto a medias, me gustan algunos más que otros, pero en general no tanto. No percibo esa amistad "verdadera" o "fluida" que dejó el elenco de Persona 4. Aún así, están bastante bien, ya que para ser los típicos estereotipes de personajes anime, estos si presentan un desarrollo con el paso del tiempo (y cómo no, el juego dura como 100 horas)

Por último me enfocaré en el tema de el contenido extra de ROYAL. Hice dos runs como de costumbre, una solo con el contenido vanilla y el último con los nuevos agregados. Debo decir que estuvo exquisito. Me gustó infinitamente más que el arco final del juego vanilla. Sumire es un gran personaje y una buena waifu y ni hablar del Doctor Maruki (mi padre). Adachi me gustó como antagonista por ser un loco desquiciado, pero es que Maruki es otro nivel. Son de esos antagonistas que te hacen simpatizar con sus acciones e ideales, se podría decir que son mas anti héroes, pero ese título le queda mejor al edgy de Akechi, que por cierto, también se lució y redimió en este último arco. Vean la escena post créditos, por favor.

En conclusión. Persona 5 Royal es un juego que [b] DEBES [/b] de jugar si te gusta la saga o los jrpg en general. Ya que no presenta continuidad con los juegos anteriores, salvo cameos o menciones de personajes.
Persona 5 Royal es un juego con alma y con una identidad diferente a los demás, incluso podría recomendárselo a aquellos que no les gusta los JRPGs ni los combates por turnos, ya que el juego está tan bien hecho que no te vas a perder así seas un manco.

Eso es todo sobre mi opinión, me encantó estas 160 horas de juego. Dejarlo al 100% este tipo de juegos que te encantan con todo el ser, se siente verdaderamente magnífico. Solo toca esperar al Persona 3 Reload que tiene una pintaza y le tengo unas ganas, que se viene a casa día uno. 

PD: Castren a Morgana
PD 2: Futaba es la best waifu

After finishing it again for the first time since my 6 playthroughs in 2020, I can confidently say that it is still one of my favorite games of all time. I cannot recommend it enough, even if games like Persona 4, Persona 2, Shin Megami Tensei Digital Devil Saga are better stories, I feel this is the best beginner's experience for people who want to get into games like this. Just be prepared to be depressed after you finish the game though.

Also Atlus please stop milking this game, it's amazing but I think we are all ready for Persona 6 now.

Persona 5 es uno de los mejores JRPG que e tenido la oportunidad de jugarlo.
La Historia es un punto fuerte de inicio a fin y es un motivarte para seguir jugando con tramas mas crudos y fuerte que tocan ejemplos el abuso de menores, la corrupción política, abuso de las empresas grandes, un mundo falso de felicidad, etc. 
Los personajes no se quedan atrás aun que parezcan estereotipos sacado de los animes son personajes tridimensionales que saben romper esos estereotipos de desarrollos que ha medida que juegues es imposible no encariñarte con los personajes a medida que avances en sus tramas y agarrar un favorito y los secundarios mas de lo mismo pesar que mucho en la trama principal siguen siendo de los mejores escritos a pesar estar en segundo plano.
El gampley es una combinación de dos tipos de juegos la exploración de mazmorra y vida social.
el de la exploración de mazmorras es de toda la vida, exploras zonas desconocidas con tu equipo eliminando enemigos con un estilo de rpg por turnos aun que sea de turnos que no es el rpg mas favorito de la gente es el mejor sistema que puede disfrutar al mas fan de los rpgs y al menos fan de genero y eso es muy positivo, con un jefe final para llegar al final de la mazmorra con un deleite visual y sonora (que ya llegaremos a eso) y la vida social aun que parezca lo mas simple es uno de los modo mejores desarrollados. Para empezar tienes el estado social, el estado social consiste de Inteligencia, Coraje, Amabilidad, Destreza y Belleza. consiste en mejorar eso estados para poder hacer cosas en la vida o seguir la trama de los personaje que mencione lo anteriormente y como se mejora el estado haciendo cosas ejemplo: si quieres mejorar amabilidad trabaja en tiendas con clientes amables. si quieres mejorar coraje ve películas de terror o anda al gimnasio asi con los demás estados sociales. también tiene el sistema de calendario es lo mas simple del mundo el sistema consiste en hacer cosas en dia para pasar el siguiente dia y ya pero por que es importante que en el juego te lo explica de mejor manera.
El apartado visual y sonoro es de lo mas rico del juego la música es lo mejor del mundo y el apartado visual es lo mejor con detalles tanto de la música y del arte que tiene hará feliz a cualquiera que le gusta en ambos mundos de la música de visual.
Mi opinión: Es un juego que me marco es uno de los mejores que e jugando en todo los juegos que tuve en la vida lo recomiendo a todos ya sea que no te guste o no dale una oportunidad no te vas a arrepentir gracias por leer por esta reseña uy nos vemos en otro juego

144356565.review:
Persona 5 Royal is truly one of the most interesting and unique games I have ever played. The balance of being a model high school student pushing through exams, being called upon randomly in class while dozing off, or getting chalk thrown at you by a psycho teacher, by day and a "save-the-world vigilante" by night, is truly such an immersive and enjoyable experience. 

The story told is always interesting. Getting to learn about your friends and enemies is a really rewarding and exciting part of the game. So much so that I found myself upset that I wouldn't be able to hang out with this friend or that friend because a story beat is coming the next day. 

The life-sim aspect of Persona 5 Royal was the highlight of the game for me. Having to decide who or what to spend my time with each day was extremely engaging. Should I study? Hang out with a friend? Go see a movie at a theater to make myself more charming? Try and eat a giant burger to be more gutsy? Try and seduce my doctor? Or fight a bunch of monsters and/or do the big story content? This was easily the most fun part of the game for me and what kept me playing.  

I have never been a huge fan of turn based combat but I did have a lot of fun with various aspects of Persona 5's combat system. Most of the boss fights were also very intriguing with the combat and the story leading up to them through the palaces that you fight through to get to the final boss. These palaces always felt fresh and were a genuine blast to go through each and every time. 

My biggest gripe with Persona 5 Royal is just the sheer amount of dialogue shoved at you over and over again. I do not know just how many times my protagonist had a conversation with someone or a group of people just to get a text or phone call basically having that entire conversation all over again. This happened constantly sometimes the same conversation is repeated multiple times over the course of a couple weeks. While the characters are extremely interesting and the dialogue is fun and engaging it does get quite annoying to have the same thing repeated to you over and over and over again. 

There were also some extremely long stretches of cutscenes that had me pause and take a little break before wanting to pick up the controller to hold for another 30 minutes before I could have control of my character again. This is not necessarily a bad thing. But I thought it was worth mentioning. 

All in all Persona 5 Royal was an all around great experience. A fantastic lineup of characters to get to know and grow bonds with and a thoroughly enjoyable story jam-packed into an 100+ long game but those 100 hours will still leave you wanting to spend more time with its characters and its world once it is over,

9/10

144337129.review:
Combat? Fun. Music? Catchy. Style and Flair? Plenty.

It's easy for hours to melt away as you play Persona 5 Royal. Between tearing through Shadows, making friends with an array of characters, increasing your stats, fishing (for those so inclined), and just day to jam packed day stuff in Tokyo. The game does its best to make it feel like everything Joker does can help improve himself; both as a Phantom Thief and as a person. Confidants are even more incentivized than previous game's social links, because they help you in mementos and palaces. The Jazz club and Penguin Sniper help improve your party members. Jobs can lead to new connections (though really, we do them once or twice for the requests). Technicals have also been improved from the vanilla version, making them feel worthwhile to use.

There are lower points in the game. Some of the story beats towards the middle can feel weaker, though the bombastic starts and ends do make up for it. With some of the mementos perks, it can be very easy to overlevel, making an occasionally difficult game easy. That is not even mentioning a certain DLC persona that trivializes the game. At the very least, there isn't a story locked behind that paywall.

Overall, even if you did play the vanilla version, Royal is worth it. The additional content and updates to combat are worth experiencing.

Tantas cosas por describir a Persona 5 Royal, cada tiempo que pasas en el juego lo vale, la historia, la jugabilidad. 144188331.review:
The power of friendship made into a game, that would be the summary I would give to the Persona saga; and truth is, I love it. I know it doesn't need another review, at this point, but I want to anyway. Before that, let's take a step back, to when I first met this saga, at the hands of Persona 4, a game that to this day remains one of my favorites and I don't think it will ever be dethroned.

Persona 4 completely captivated me, and turned me into an Atlus fan (although I had played Devil Survivor and SMT: Strange Journey before, they hadn't captured me as much as this one), so I waited anxiously for Persona 5 to finally come to PC. I dodged heavy spoilers for years, looked the other way when the anime came out, and even when it showed up in stores, already within my reach, I had to keep waiting until I could buy it... and damn, it was worth it, very worth it.

Persona 5 is a JRPG that has captured the hearts of many gamers (pun intended), and offers not only a story full of touching and exciting moments, but also a gameplay that, while maintaining the soul of its predecessors, adds modernizing changes and very cool mechanics, as well as improving on what was already there.

This time, the [b]story[/b] puts us in the role of a guy who was a victim of society's corruption, framed for an assault he did not commit, and being forced to change schools while carrying the label of criminal. But this event will lead him to meet some mysterious jailers from an alternate world, who’ll help him in his journey and with his "rehabilitation", which will be explained to us gradually.

Little by little, the plot will be revealed to us, and we’ll awaken our powers (I'll get to that later) as we become familiar with the city and its inhabitants. Throughout our adventure, we’ll recruit companions who share the will of rebellion; and with them, we’ll form the band of thieves of hearts; that is, pretty much, the central theme of the game, and I thought it was phenomenal! It's a story with several clichés, but overflowing with genius and a setting that I simply loved, and it must be said that it's carried on the shoulders of endearing characters that I won't soon forget. 

The [b]gameplay[/b] is similar to the previous game, but with several entertaining improvements. Something that returns practically immaculate is having a certain amount of time in the day (usually afternoon and evening) to perform our activities; this is why we must choose carefully what to do each day, because once we decide, time will pass and there will be no turning back. There are many things to do and unlock, so planning our decisions a little is not so bad either.

In our free time, either after school or on free days, we can explore the city and visit different places and stores, do some activity that increases our parameters, or simply hang out with our companions to strengthen our bonds. Bonds, or social links, are very important in this saga, and represent the "level" of friendship we have with certain individuals. 

Each bond will have its different benefits depending on the level, and the goal is to raise them to the maximum to get the most out of them. For example, raising the "death" bond, with the local doctor, gives us a repertoire of medicines that expands as we help her with her work and get to know her better. In the case of the companions that we can bring in the group, they usually get skills more focused on combat.

Touching on the subject of combat, it is the classic turn-based group combat, where we can go with up to four characters at the same time and battle against the "shadows" that reside in an alternate world, called the "metaverse" (no, not Facebook’s). In this place we'll find what the game presents as "palaces", where powerful shadows that are the manifestation of the most twisted desires of certain individuals reign; and our job as thieves of hearts, is to trace a route within these palaces, reach the treasure, and steal it, so that these people have a "change of heart". We also need to sell a calling card before the heist, in all-good phantom thieves fashion!

Within the combat we'll have Personas, powerful creatures that represent our will, our other self, and so on. While our companions have their own Persona, the protagonist is able to invite the shadows of the metaverse to join him, in order to get their cooperation and special abilities; this is what makes him stand out, since he is like a wildcard, versatile and can adapt to any situation (especially because each Persona also has its own attributes, such as weakness/strength to fire, lightning, etc.).

Outside of combat, the exploration of the palaces is made interesting thanks to some creative mechanics, such as being able to hide in the shadows and behind obstacles to set up ambushes (and thus start the fight with an advantage), or dodge enemies to proceed without fighting. We'll also have thief tools, such as lock picks to open chests, or a zipline gun to hook ourselves around and look very cool flying through the air, as well as to reach high places, I guess. All in all, this section is one of the most entertaining, and I feel that they improved quite a bit the combat and exploration compared to the previous installment; I must say that there's still a lot I haven't mentioned, but I'll put a stop here.

The game's [b]art[/b] section is just great, from the title screen to the character designs; there's no other game that made me think "how cool are these menus" over and over, really. The 3D models looked great to me, especially after coming from playing SMT 3: Nocturne, as I was able to have a pretty clear comparison, and I was delighted. If I had to decide on one word to sum it all up, it would be style. Bosses are badass, Personas are so cool looking, it’s just all great.

The [b]soundtrack[/b] is no slouch either, giving off a majestic vibe in all of the game's tunes. I especially loved the tracks in Mementos, one of the game's mazes, and the weapon store; they're great. It's worth noting that one of the main songs is the one heard in the background in countless YouTube videos, to give an example of how good this is. In short, an immaculate audiovisual section, and I expected nothing less!

In [b]conclusion[/b], Persona 5 Royal takes the essentials of the franchise and elevates it to its maximum splendor, adding novelties and with a super entertaining story, which does not neglect a cast of characters that I became attached to as if they were my own friends. It is a detailed, stylized and charismatic game, and I hated to see how it slowly reached the end, because I really didn't want to let go (although, truth be told, I spent the final stretch grinning from ear to ear, very moved). But, same as in 4, that's the idea, not to hold on to the past and move forward, face reality; or at least that's how I came to interpret it. A great game that leaves me both anxious for Atlus' next games and satisfied, its popularity is well deserved, and I don't hesitate to recommend it, not even a little bit.

143941164.review:
[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Incredible presentation and execution, P5R is a rich tale of anti-corruption/authority that engages the player in a balanced mixed mode of narrative story/world building and turn-based combat
    [*]Is not connected to Persona 4 Golden and not required to enjoy P5R, however, certain themes/systems are present
    [*]Style.  From the menu's to the loading screen transitions, there is so much detail to the world of Shibuya; phenomenal use of sound effects, background white noise, NPC dialogue, and animations
    [*]Music.  Relaxing jazz to heavy rock and metal, P5R excels at setting the mood and tone of each scene.
    [*]Plethora of activities.  Many ways to spend your time and perform new actions every day.  Each event has a benefit so you never "lose" days
    [*]Trivia & school knowledge.  Student of history, anthropology, mythos creatures, or coffee?  Prepare to learn interesting information regarding a variety of subjects that may or may not be beneficial to your life
    [*]Great QOL.  Occasionally, the game will remind you of activities that you may have forgotten or that have been introduced recently.  Finished with an area in the shadow world? you're given the option to head straight to your next destination.  Simple solutions, but greatly appreciated attention to detail
    [*]Combat is simple and designed to be cinematic and movie like.  There are many functions that make combat a thrill to engage in such as: all-out, showtimes, follow-ups, and baton passes; difficulty can be adjusted at any time
    [*]Mementos.  For P5R's long palace, it is well paced and story gated so that players don't get burnt out through exploring while also encouraging multiple visits through requests
    [*]Multiple secret bosses and challenges that test your might and knowledge of Personas and fusion building
    [*]Thieves Den.  Essentially the gallery collection, but also acts as a "backstage" or "behind the scenes" for the player to interact with.  Characters and confidants that you have encountered in the game will be present here and will interact with each other about story events or locations; can make for some interesting dialogue matches
    [*][b]Akechi {My Rival}[/b] & [b]Clara {Best Maid}[/b]
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Would be beneficial to be able to discard current Personas in the velvet room so that you needn't back out of dialogue to discard
    [*]Confidant decorations should carry over to NG+ (Why can't I keep my LED Skytree lamp)
    [*]Lots of flashy animations, bright colors, and quick movements and effects.  Could trigger epileptic responses for some players
    [*]Tycoon Avalanche (Not as hard as Yakuza's mahjong riichi though)
[/list]

143746305.review:
Je ne suis peut-être pas super objectif car j'adore l'univers Shin Megami Tensei et donc par extension les Persona. J'avais déjà adoré le 4 et je ne suis pas déçu par le 5.
Il faut bien préciser que ce jeu n'est pas pour tout le monde. En effet, c'est un mix entre un J-RPG au tour par tour et un visual novel.
Tous les Persona sont de cette trempe, il y a donc énoooormément de dialogues, mais c'est ce qui permet de s'attacher aux personnages.
En s'attachant aux personnages, on entre dans l'histoire de manière plus profonde.
Les Persona se déroulent tout le temps dans le cadre du lycée mais les thèmes abordés sont toujours plus profonds qu'on pourrait le croire.
Pour ce dernier, citons entre autres : le suicide, les abus sexuels, les attentes de la société/la famille (avec un minimum de connaissance sur le Japon, on comprend très vite pourquoi), la politique, la justice, la corruption ...
Pour les néofites, disons que c'est un "pokemon-like" en extrêmement plus adulte, plus beau avec des possibilités de fusion incroyables. Il y a une vraie profondeur dans l'histoire.
Si vous aimez les J-RPG, les jeux avec un vrai background et n'avez pas peur de passer du temps à lire des dialogues FONCEZ !

GATO DE MIERDA, DÉJAME MOVERME QUE SOLO QUIERO HACER UN CAFÉ, TÚ QUÉ VAS A SABER SI ESTOY CANSADO O NO!

Adultos de mierda: El videojuego
Persona 5 Royal no es solo uno de los mejores juegos que he jugado en los últimos años, sino también el mejor JRPG que se ha hecho a día de hoy.

El estilo que tiene, su arte, la música, los personajes a los que terminas agarrándole cariño después de 100 HORAS que dura, y eso el juego principal. Puedes estar en la hora 45 y aún te están enseñando alguna cosa. 

Con un sistema de confidentes en los que puedes salir con cada personaje secundario a hacer cosas de adolescente normal y esto subirá el nivel de su confidente, lo que te dará nuevos poderes y mejoras y a su vez desarrollará la historia de cada personaje, y en el caso de los personajes femeninos puedes convertirte en su amante. 

Con una historia que trata temas como el Suicidio, el abuso sexual, manipulación, la violencia, las drogas, las altas expectativas que ponen los adultos en los más jóvenes y cómo esto les afecta, etc. A pesar de que pueda parecer un juego para "niños", puedes esperar una historia bastante buena que trata temas adultos, aunque a veces los personajes se pasan de subnormales tirándote todo a la cara, pero en general es muy buena y te atrapa, siempre queriendo saber más

El arte y la música son magníficos, pocos juegos con tanto estilo y personalidad como este, 11/10 en estos apartados.

Pues eso, que lo juegues y ya, una absoluta joya, y si lo empiezas hoy a lo mejor te da tiempo a acabarlo antes de que salga el Persona 3 Reload.

143535047.review: Well known solid buy.  A long game.  Took me a bit to get into it myself, but my playthrough of the PC version is the second, first of Royal version. A bit "rotten adults" and "Rah rah save the world," and I find myself cringing from that, but even still I enjoy following the story, even on my second run (a rarity for me) and enjoy the characters.  Definitely make your first play through blind.  You'll miss a lot of confidants and helpful skills, but playing it "as you would" making decisions as you'd make them, rather than to maximize your abilities, makes the life sim end of it more enjoyable.
